dialogues.speaker: NIGHT 1
dialogues.text: A SERIES OF VERY TIGHT CLOSEUPS: a convict, FRANK BEACHUM, is being examined by a prison doctor, DOCTOR ROGER WATERS. We do not see his face until the end of the sequence. Instead we see only the parts of his body that are being examined, and from these we can tell that he is black, well-muscled, and in his late twenties. CLOSEUP ON his chest as his prison shirt (stenciled CP- 133) comes off. A stethoscope against his chest. Dr. Waters looking down at his watch. Second hand of the watch.

dialogues.speaker: DR. WATERS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Sixty-five. Normal. The prisoner's muscular arm, with a blood-pressure cuff on it. Dr. Waters rips off the cuff. Underneath is a mean-looking tattoo of a bleeding heart with a knife through it.

dialogues.speaker: DR. WATERS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Blood pressure, one twenty over seventy- five. Normal. The prisoner's legs. Dr. Waters taps his knee with a reflex hammer.

dialogues.speaker: DR. WATERS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Reflexes normal. The prisoner's mouth, open, with a tongue depressor stuck in it. The prisoner gags: "Agh!"

dialogues.speaker: DR. WATERS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Looks fine. Healthy as a horse. CLOSEUP of a clock on the wall: 10:17. The face of LUTHER PLUNKITT, the San Quentin Prison warden, watching the examination, and then looking at the clock. Plunkitt is white, fortyish, and a little soft in the gut. He's seen enough in his years at San Quentin to be neither a pushover nor a martinet. To him, the exam is routine, but he's also mindful of its significance: It's the final exam before Beachum's execution in about twenty six hours. He nods toward a guard who is sitting at a typewriter. The guard types. CLOSEUP of the page in the typewriter. It's the prisoner's chronological. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUE CRIME - Rev. 5/11/98 2.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The guard types: "22:17 -- med exam completed."

dialogues.speaker: DR. WATERS
dialogues.text: Just one more thing, Luther. Plunkitt looks at the doctor. Then at Beachum.

dialogues.speaker: PLUNKITT
dialogues.text: You gotta whizz in the cup, Frank. Then we're done. CLOSEUP of Beachum's face. We see that he is young, and that he might have been scary once -- might, in fact, have been someone's worst nightmare. Now there's something else in his face: a terrible weariness, hopelessness mingled with the struggle against fear. As the CREDITS END, the clock on the wall ticks to 10:18.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A stretch of parkway that swings to the left at an acute angle. A gas station, closed, is situated to the right of the turn's apex. Warning signs and blinking yellow lights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The warm wooden interior is hung with lanterns and ads for microbrews. At the bar sits STEVE EVERETT, a newspaperman with the face of a smart-ass. He has wicked eyebrows and a wicked smile. Everett is thin-waisted, broad-shouldered, and muscular from lifting weights. He is having a drink -- a non-alcoholic drink -- with MICHELLE ZIEGLER, a novice reporter who is very young, very alluring, and very ambitious. Her skirt is too short, and her lustrous eyes gleam with the superiority of the recent college graduate.

dialogues.speaker: MICHELLE
dialogues.text: Well, fuck ‘em.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: (sighing) Oh, God. Now we're going to talk journalism.

dialogues.speaker: MICHELLE
dialogues.text: You call this journalism? You're telling me that --

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Michelle, it's been a long weekend. People kept shooting each other. I kept writing about it...

dialogues.speaker: MICHELLE
dialogues.text: I'm serious. I've had enough of this crap. I'm going back to school, get my Ph.D. -- write things that matter.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Michelle, I hate to break this to you, but you're twenty-three. You don't know anything that matters.

dialogues.speaker: MICHELLE
dialogues.text: (laughing) And fuck you too, Ev.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: All right, pull up a shoulder. What'd they do to you? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MICHELLE
dialogues.text: Not they. He -- Alan. Killed my sidebar on the Frank Beachum murder. If you ask me, something about the whole case stinks anyway, but what I was trying to get at --

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Michelle, I read that sidebar --

dialogues.speaker: MICHELLE
dialogues.text: Hey, it was good, Ev. You gotta admit. Best stuff I've written in months.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah. Wasn't that the piece about!-- now don't let me fuck this up: ‘the media glorified Beachum's victim in order to mask our patriarchal culture...’

dialogues.speaker: MICHELLE
dialogues.text: Which created the very violence that destroyed her! Exactly!

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Alan shouldn't have killed it like that.

dialogues.speaker: MICHELLE
dialogues.text: Fuckin' A.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: I would have tortured it first. Michelle laughs in spite of herself and gives Everett a naughty look.

dialogues.speaker: MICHELLE
dialogues.text: It might've enjoyed that.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Honey, it would have begged for more. The bartender, NEIL, pokes his head over the bar.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: ‘Nother round?

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Yeah, Neil. Margarita for the lady, and my usual.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: Not your usual usual. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: My new, improved usual.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: Virgin Mary.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Yeah. Heavy on the virgin. Michelle looks at him curiously.

dialogues.speaker: MICHELLE
dialogues.text: Tell me something, Ev. If you're such a hot shit, what are you doing stuck here in Bumfuck, California?

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: (sliding closer) Looking for love. She lets him put his arm around her.

dialogues.speaker: MICHELLE
dialogues.text: Well, you've come to all the wrong places.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: (closer) Not from where I sit. For a moment they melt into each other's arms. Then Michelle pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: MICHELLE
dialogues.text: No. Unh-unh. Not smart.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: What's smart got to do with it?

dialogues.speaker: MICHELLE
dialogues.text: I gotta go. I can't do this. You're married and you're -- I can't do this! She gets up and wobbles out of the bar. Everett watches her, more amused than sorry. He glances at the bartender, Neil, who is just arriving with the drinks. Neil shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: Next time.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: (winking) Next time for sure.  10 11

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michelle exits into the rain, a sexy little grin on her face: "Next time for sure."

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT, (LIGHT RAIN)
dialogues.text: Michelle is driving, still smiling to herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THROUGH her windshield, smeared, the wipers ragged, the road barely visible.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT, (RAIN)
dialogues.text: Michelle turns ON the RADIO. ALTERNATIVE ROCK pumps into the car. Michelle responds enthusiastically, dancing in her bucket seat, beating on the steering wheel. She's feeling good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The same angle as before. It's coming up much too quickly. The car's tire catches the edge of a retaining wall and jerks sideways.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michelle swings the wheel violently; the car zig-zags and slides sideways into the gas station lot. The wall of the station hurtles toward us.

dialogues.speaker: MICHELLE
dialogues.text: Please! The CAR SMASHES head-on into the wall. Michelle rips through the windshield; the GLASS EXPLODES outward. The GRIND of METAL AGAINST METAL, and then, gradually, the NOISE SUBSIDES. The smoke settles, revealing a hole in the windshield framed by a crumpled steering column. The HISS of hot, leaking FLUIDS SLOWLY SEGUES INTO... ... the sound of a POWER MOWER.

dialogues.speaker: BEACHUM'S HANDS
dialogues.text: Gripping a lawn mower. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Green grass, sunshine, a small white house against a blue sky. BONNIE, a pleasant-looking young black woman, calls to him from the barbecue. In her hand is a small brown object, which she waggles back and forth. From under the sound of the mower, the COOING of a BABY. We LOOK DOWN AND TO THE RIGHT: There's a plastic sandbox shaped like a turtle, and in it is Frank's little daughter, GAIL, whacking the sand with her shovel and cooing at her father. Beachum's gaze returns to Bonnie, still calling to him, waggling something.

dialogues.speaker: BEACHUM
dialogues.text: What?... Just hold on. I can't hear you. The sound of the LAWN MOWER GRADUALLY TURNS INTO a CLACKING sound -- the sound of a TYPEWRITER. END OF DREAM SEQUENCE.

dialogues.speaker: PRISON TYPEWRITER
dialogues.text: We see the chronological being typed: "6:21 -- prisoner awakes."

dialogues.speaker: BEACHUM'S FACE
dialogues.text: His eyes fly open. He jerks up, looking around him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the bars he sees the duty officer, REEDY, typing.

dialogues.speaker: REEDY
dialogues.text: Morning, Frank. Beachum nods.

dialogues.speaker: REEDY
dialogues.text: Can I get you anything? Some breakfast? Beachum sags, pulls himself up, struggles to answer.

dialogues.speaker: BEACHUM
dialogues.text: If you got, like, a roll? Some coffee?

dialogues.speaker: REEDY
dialogues.text: We'll get that right away, Frank. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Reedy types, then gets up and murmurs to another guard stationed outside the cell. Then Reedy sits down and types again. We see the words: "6:24 -- Breakfast order relayed to CO Drummond."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're in the bowels of the building. Two large presses crank out the next edition. It's hot and noisy and dirty down here, just the way ALAN MANN likes it. Alan emerges from the cafeteria carrying an extra large Styrofoam cup of coffee. He stops to schmooze with the guys who run the presses -- newspaper guys, ink-stained and tough. Alan is tall and broad-shouldered, with a belly that hangs over his belt; he looks like an athlete gone to seed. He's the newspaper's editor-in-chief. BOB FINDLEY, the city editor, is younger and softer. As he approaches Alan, he is wearing a neatly-pressed pink shirt and a cheerful tie; no jacket. Bob composes his face and takes a deep breath. He prides himself on being caring. Just now, he has the look of a man who is about to impart some serious news.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: You hear?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: What a tragedy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They enter. Alan punches "four" with his free hand and impatiently stabs at the "close door" button.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: What was she, drunk?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: (a pained smile) I don't know. It was up at -- you know, that vicious turn onto the parkway? They ought to do something about that place. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Do we have to cover for her? Did she have anything big on?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: She had that interview with Frank Beachum at San Quentin. Then she was going to witness the execution tonight.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Christ.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: It's a little worse for Michelle, Alan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A large, chaotic open space partitioned into smaller cubicles. Alan crosses the city section where a handful of reporters are making phone calls and pecking away at computer keyboards. Bob follows, a few paces behind.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I don't know if the warden'1ll go for a replacement on the interview with Beachum. But I thought I'd take Harvey off the fraud meeting and --

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Put Everett on it.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Steve? Uh, Steve's got the day off.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Not any more he hasn't. He can do the interview, then he can witness the execution. What's-his-face, the warden down at San Quentin -- Plunkitt. Steve's dealt with him before. I can get him in. They pass JANE MARCH, Bob's assistant. She catches his eye and offers a sympathetic look: ‘What a tragedy."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alan strides in, with Bob right behind him. Bob shuts the door. Alan stands behind his desk.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: You think Everett's an asshole. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUE CRIME - Rev. 5/11/98 10.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I don't think he's an asshole.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: You're wrong. He is an asshole. Trust me: I know him. A lot of people who're good at their jobs are assholes, Bob. Alan plunks himself into his seat, reaches into his inside coat pocket, and removes a packet of crumb cake, which he slams down on the desk as though making a declaration. He opens his coffee and looks up expectantly at Bob.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: (earnestly) I know that, Alan. It's just, Everett thinks everything's a big investigative witch hunt. Like on that Mike Vargas piece --

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: He was a drunk then. He's not now.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Right. Two months ago he was a drunk, now he's sober -- if you say so, Alan. Anyway, that's beside the point. The point is, this isn't a Steve Everett slash-and-burn job. It's a sidebar. It's an issue piece.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: (wide-eyed) Ooh! An issue piece! Well, dog my cats!

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Come on, Alan. Capital punishment -- you know. I mean, the state is putting aman to death tonight. Killing a human being.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: (enjoying this) Oh, well, stop the presses! Hey, was Amy whatsherface, the pregnant broad old Frankie shot in the chest -- was she a human being? Is that part of the issue?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Okay, yeah. That's part of the issue.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Crumb cake? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: No. No.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Let me tell you something, Bob. Issues are the shit we make up to give us an excuse to run good stories. Judge grabs a female attorney's tits, that's the sex discrimination issue. Nine-year-old kills his brother with an Uzi, that's the child violence issue. People want to read about sex organs and blood. We make up issues so they don't have to feel too nasty about it.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I guess I should call Steve Everett then. Because that's his attitude exactly.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: (leaning back) Bob, you've been here, what? Three months now? I've been working with Steve Everett for three and a half years, and let me tell you something: The guy is good, as good as I've ever seen. You know why he was kicked out of New York? You know the story?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I've heard a coupla things.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Steve Everett busted the mayor, Bob. The mayor of fucking New York City. Steve got hold of a secret memo on a contract bribe between Hizzoner and one of the ex-borough presidents, and he ran with it in his column.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: So?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: The paper tried to kill it, ‘cause the owner was in bed with the mayor. So what'd Everett do? Didn't whine -- didn't back down, either. He walked. A long silence. Bob shoves his hands in his pockets.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: All right. All right, it's your paper. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: And, Bob -- when you send flowers to the girl's family, would you include my name? Thanks. 'Preciate it. Bob goes out. Alan watches him for a moment, smiles and shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Gullible bastard.

dialogues.speaker: TOILET
dialogues.text: where Everett, stark naked, is emptying an ashtray. Butts fall into the bowl, and then we see hands using toilet paper to wipe out the ashes. We hear Everett's voice, as though he's talking to someone in another room.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hey, I could have been happy in New York forever -- They were about to let me run the investigative team. That would have put me on the Pulitzer track. He finishes the job and emerges into the adjoining bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the mussed bed, looking wondrously shapely and wondrously naked, is PATRICIA FINDLEY, Bob's wife. She watches Everett's approach admiringly, but there is something sardonic in her smile. Everett puts the ashtray on a bedside table.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: It was a nice life -- Broadway shows, downtown clubs, Elaine's every night, veal chops up the wazoo. He does a little dance, singing James Brown's "Got the Feeling," playing imaginary maracas.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: ‘Baby, baby, baa-by. Baby, baby, baa- by. Baby, baby, baa-by.' ‘Course, they never served anything like this. He swoops down and bites Patricia on the buttock.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICIA
dialogues.text: Ooh! Now you have to kiss it and make it better. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Everett does. And while he's still kissing:

dialogues.speaker: PATRICIA
dialogues.text: So you were the king of New York. Why are you hacking out Metro stories at the Oakland Tribune?

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Got caught in the supply room with a seventeen-year-old desk assistant.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICIA
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Yup. Turned out to be the daughter of the paper's owner. Blackballed me all over town.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICIA
dialogues.text: You bad man! What'd your wife say?

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: (not without pain) Well, we'd just had the kid, you know. It was tough on her, but she wanted to keep us together. And when Alan said he'd take me on, I guess she figured, you know, another town, another change.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICIA
dialogues.text: You bad man. First the owner's daughter. Now the editor's wife. Do I detect a hostility toward authority figures?

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Only the ones I work for.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICIA
dialogues.text: And is that what you're going to say in the next city, with someone else? (imitating him) Oh, I got caught with the editor's wife. You know how that is. Everett gets up and begins pulling on his pants.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: I get caught with you, I don't know how many other cities will have me. Patricia watches him dress, affecting a pout. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PATRICIA
dialogues.text: So playtime's over?

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: You gotta get to work. I gotta get home. See if the wife and kid still recognize me.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICIA
dialogues.text: You're not going to tell me how awful we're being, are you?

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Well... Bob's a decent guy. Good newspaperman. Solid editor.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICIA
dialogues.text: So this all just stinks, right? What we're doing.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: You and me, Patricia, we're just two simple people swept away in a whirlwind of passion. Something like that. Everett finishes putting on his shirt and bends over to give her a kiss. Then he turns away, looking for his wallet and keys.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICIA
dialogues.text: Look, it's all right. It's not like I love you or anything.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: (smiling) Thanks. I don't love you too. The PHONE RINGS. She picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICIA
dialogues.text: Hello? Uh... All right... Everett makes for the door, blowing her a kiss and mouthing a "bye." But Patricia holds up her index finger: "Wait a second."

dialogues.speaker: PATRICIA
dialogues.text: (on the phone) Yes... yes, all right. She hangs up and then looks at Everett, who is waiting expectantly. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 19 20 21 TRUE CRIME - Rev. 5/11/98 15.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICIA
dialogues.text: You won't believe this.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICIA
dialogues.text: That was Bob.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: What'd he want?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICIA
dialogues.text: He was looking for you. Everett is stunned.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Who told him?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICIA
dialogues.text: How the hell should I know? Everett looks at her, hard. He wheels and heads out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Plunkitt steps into the cell. Reedy stands in front of his typewriter. Plunkitt nods and turns toward the prisoner. Beachum sits at a small table behind a wall of bars. The table is covered with several sheets of paper and a Bic pen. Beachum holds a cigarette between two of his fingers, sending a zig-zag of smoke to the ceiling. The ash has grown long. It drops to the table of its own weight. Beachum doesn't move his hand at all.

dialogues.speaker: PLUNKITT
dialogues.text: Morning, Frank. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BEACHUM
dialogues.text: (softly, respectfully) Mr. Plunkitt.

dialogues.speaker: PLUNKITT
dialogues.text: Anything I can get for you? Anything you need?

dialogues.speaker: BEACHUM
dialogues.text: No. Can't think of nothin’. Beachum is eerily still, his eyes cast to the floor.

dialogues.speaker: PLUNKITT
dialogues.text: There're some matters I gotta discuss with you. Figure we do it first thing, get it out of the way. Frank nods slowly, as if it were a very great effort.

dialogues.speaker: PLUNKITT
dialogues.text: Your dinner tonight, for one thing. It can be pretty much anything you want. Frank nods again. More ash falls to the floor.

dialogues.speaker: PLUNKITT
dialogues.text: You go ‘head and tell Reedy here when you decide. Now, about your personal effects and belongings --

dialogues.speaker: BEACHUM
dialogues.text: My wife'll take ‘em.

dialogues.speaker: PLUNKITT
dialogues.text: And your remains? Does that go for your remains, too? Because if she can't afford the funeral expenses --

dialogues.speaker: BEACHUM
dialogues.text: No, no. Her church raised some money. It's all right.

dialogues.speaker: PLUNKITT
dialogues.text: So your wife will be claiming your remains, then. Frank draws a breath. He straightens slightly and his plastic chair scrapes the floor. Plunkitt winces a bit at the sound.

dialogues.speaker: BEACHUM
dialogues.text: Yes sir, that's right. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUE CRIME - Rev. 5/11/98 17.

dialogues.speaker: PLUNKITT
dialogues.text: Okay. Now, I want to give you some idea here of what's going to happen tonight. We'll have to ask your visitors to leave at seven P.M. You'll be given your dinner and a fresh set of clothes. There's a sort of plastic underwear thing we have to ask you to put on. No one'll be able to see it or anything, but we need it for sanitary purposes. We'll make sure it's removed before your wife claims the body. Plunkitt pauses and stares at Beachum's cigarette, at the ash lengthening on the end of it. Then he snaps himself back.

dialogues.speaker: PLUNKITT
dialogues.text: We'll come for you, oh, about a half hour before the procedure. You'll be taken into the procedure room and they'1l hook an E.K.G. up to you and the intravenous lines at that time. But nothing's gonna happen early or anything. Right up until 12:01, we'll be monitoring the phones. We got open lines to the attorney general and the governor, and those'll be checked right through to make sure they're in working order. You got any questions about any of that?

dialogues.speaker: BEACHUM
dialogues.text: (very, very quietly) No.

dialogues.speaker: PLUNKITT
dialogues.text: Now, there's just one more thing, and then I'll leave you in peace here. It's about the sedative. Beachum stiffens. The line of smoke coming up from his cigarette smears as his hand shakes.

dialogues.speaker: BEACHUM
dialogues.text: I don't want no sedative.

dialogues.speaker: PLUNKITT
dialogues.text: Sedative's completely optional, Frank. I would just like to advise you that it can make things a whole lot easier. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 21 22 TRUE CRIME - Rev. 5/11/98 18.

dialogues.speaker: BEACHUM
dialogues.text: (tightly) I don't want it. (beat) I appreciate it, Mr. Plunkitt. But I wanna be clear in my mind. When I see my wife, I wanna be clear for that. All right?

dialogues.speaker: PLUNKITT
dialogues.text: Fair enough. You change your mind, you let the duty officer know. I just had to give you my little sales talk, is all. Beachum keeps his eyes lowered, watching his hands. The cigarette has burned down to the filter, and Plunkitt stands there a moment, looking nervously at it. Finally Beachum reaches to the tinfoil ashtray next to him and crushes it out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Plunkitt is met by his deputy warden, ARNOLD McCARDLE. Arnold is a jolly fellow with sparkling eyes and a three-hundred-pound frame. Reading notes from a folder, he breathes heavily, keeping pace with Plunkitt. McCARDLE Badges'1l go down to the gate at nine. Got the witness list. What else? Roadblocks are up. Demonstrators are light so far.

dialogues.speaker: PLUNKITT
dialogues.text: Visitors all squared away? McCARDLE Wife and kid. Your girlfriend from the ‘News,' Michelle Ziegler -- she's coming at four.

dialogues.speaker: PLUNKITT
dialogues.text: Mea culpa. She was pretty persuasive. McCARDLE Hey, let her persuade me next time, would ya? Plunkitt gives him a look. They approach the death chamber. Plunkitt pauses.

dialogues.speaker: PLUNKITT
dialogues.text: Arnie, what do you think of Beachum? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: McCARDLE I don't. Sometimes I think about the girl he shot dead over 96 dollars. But mostly I think about doing my job. Plunkitt nods. "Of course, that's right." He opens the door and ushers McCardle into the death chamber.

dialogues.text: What can I get you, Frank? Shillerman shuts up and rises. Beachum rises, too, and meets Shilerman's eyes.

dialogues.speaker: BEACHUM
dialogues.text: You can get this goddamned son-of-a- bitch out of here. Calls himself a man of God... He lifts his cigarette, his hand trembling so that the ash falls off. Reedy takes Shillerman's arm.

dialogues.speaker: REEDY
dialogues.text: Reverend Shillerman... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BEACHUM
dialogues.text: (muttering) Reverend Shit-For-Brains. Shillerman's smile freezes and his eyes go red. He keeps talking to Beachum as Reedy pulls him away.

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND SHILLERMAN
dialogues.text: Now, Frank, I myself would not want to be strapped to that table tonight with the wrongs I've done unrepented of...

dialogues.speaker: REEDY
dialogues.text: Reverend, come on...

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND SHILLERMAN
dialogues.text: Because when they stick that needle in your arm, Frank...

dialogues.speaker: REEDY
dialogues.text: Jesus, Reverend, come on. Spiritual counseling's voluntary.

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND SHILLERMAN
dialogues.text: ... And you feel your blood run to ice...

dialogues.speaker: REEDY
dialogues.text: Reverend! That's enough.

dialogues.speaker: BEACHUM
dialogues.text: Get him out of here.

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND SHILLERMAN
dialogues.text: I'm sorry for you, Frank.

dialogues.speaker: BEACHUM
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, too. Believe me.

dialogues.speaker: REEDY
dialogues.text: Reverend, I mean it. We don't want no trouble here.

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND SHILLERMAN
dialogues.text: All right, all right. I just felt, it may be upsetting, but I have a job to do here, and I, I just felt... Shillerman backs into the shadows. Reedy returns to his desk.

dialogues.speaker: REEDY
dialogues.text: Everyone wants in on the action. right, Frank? (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: REEDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (beat) Frank? No longer angry, Beachum seems to have shrunk into himself. In a small voice --

dialogues.speaker: BEACHUM
dialogues.text: Yeah. He pulls another cigarette from the pack and looks at the clock: 12:01. He lights his cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: CIGARETTE 36
dialogues.text: being lit. We PULL BACK to see that it belongs to Everett.

dialogues.speaker: DAY 37
dialogues.text: The car is brown and decrepit. One of its fenders is rusted through, a taillight is secured by gaffer's tape, and two hubcaps are missing. It is what is commonly known as a shitbox. Nevertheless, Everett is driving it as though it were a Lamborghini. He has the window down and is banging on the rusty door as he (very loudly) sings along to the RADIO, which is playing "MY SHARONA." Everett makes up most of the words, but he joins lustily on the "My Sharona part.

dialogues.speaker: DAY 38
dialogues.text: The SONG ENDS and Everett switches channels.

dialogues.speaker: RADIO, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: -+. and that makes it time for a Radio 820 news update. Well, twelve hours from now, convicted killer Frank Beachum will be executed by lethal injection. This will be only the third time this method has been used by the State of California since the landmark decision...

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT'S FACE
dialogues.text: He lights a cigarette and listens. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ROAD
dialogues.text: A sign announcing: Richmond 1 mile.

dialogues.speaker: DAY 39
dialogues.text: Weaving in and out of freeway traffic.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: looking at his watch: 12:04.

dialogues.speaker: RADIO, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: .-+. Beachum was convicted six years ago of the brutal slaying of 23-year-old coed Amy Wilson and her unborn child at Pocum's Grocery in Richmond...

dialogues.speaker: EXIT SIGN
dialogues.text: along the road: Richmond next exit.

dialogues.speaker: RADIO, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ... Wilson, who was married and six months pregnant, was working as a cashier at the grocery when Beachum shot her during an argument over 96 dollars she owed him...

dialogues.speaker: RICHMOND EXIT
dialogues.text: approaching on the right.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: The Richmond exit just about to slip by.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT'S FACE
dialogues.text: Suddenly, Everett grabs the steering wheel and pulls hard to the right.

dialogues.speaker: DAY 41
dialogues.text: It plows across lanes of traffic, heading perilously for the Richmond exit. It SCREECHES onto the ramp and careens down it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car pulls into a space. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The grocery is a one-story red brick bunker with a dingy awning. To one side of the door, a Coke machine.

dialogues.speaker: FRONT WINDOW OF POCUM'S
dialogues.text: Just over a line of withering oranges and tomatoes, a hand-lettered sign has been taped: "An Eye for an Eye! Beachum has to Die!" Underneath, a dripping syringe with a death's head on the tube. Everett raises his eyebrows. He gets out of the car. As he does, he accidentally kicks something that has rolled from under his seat -- an old (very old) cantaloupe. It sploshes to the ground and shudders there for a moment. Everett makes a sometimes-I-even-gross- myself-out face, gingerly picks up the rotting cantaloupe, and throws it into the vacant lot next door. As it hits the ground and explodes, Everett makes a "bomb exploding" noise with his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The market is a long rectangle with a counter at one end, behind which sits a sullen, bloated woman in a bulging white T-shirt. The grocery racks are perpendicular to the counter, and above the counter a television is blaring. Everett stands for a moment, wiping his cantaloupe-tainted hand against his pants. On the TV screen, a reporter is doing a stand-up outside the San Quentin prison walls, talking about the somber mood there, the tight security, and so forth. Everett strolls toward the counter, looking around.

dialogues.speaker: COUNTER WOMAN
dialogues.text: (to Everett) Help you? He gives her his handsome guy smile, and, as he does, he notices a button on her T-shirt: "Remember Amy."

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: I'm a reporter. With the Tribune. Say, this is the place where the Wilson girl was killed, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: COUNTER WOMAN
dialogues.text: It sure is. She was right behind this same counter. Almost six years ago exactly. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Wow. Gee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We take in the room with him: the racks of food, the counter where the woman is still yapping at him --

dialogues.speaker: COUNTER WOMAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Mr. Pocum says the needle's too good for him. For Beachum. Me, I say they oughta bring back the chair, that's what I say. Really let him have a jolt of something. -- the two doors (the front door and, along the same wall, the service entrance to the left of the counter), and the little entryway in the back.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: What's back there?

dialogues.speaker: COUNTER WOMAN
dialogues.text: Bathroom. Mr. Pocum was always real nice about letting folks come in and do their business. Everett nods, and for a moment he is at a loss.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Well, thanks a bunch. I'm gonna come back one of these days and do some serious shopping.

dialogues.speaker: COUNTER WOMAN
dialogues.text: Am I gonna be in the newspaper? Everett doesn't answer. He's just spotted something on the floor to the side of the counter, and now he crouches down for a better look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the floor, the kind of white outlines that might have been left in the linoleum if a foot rack had once been placed there. Everett gets up.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Hey, did there used to be something here? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: COUNTER WOMAN
dialogues.text: Oh, yessir, there was. That's where we used to keep the potato chips. But Mr. Pocum moved the rack over there -- She indicates the other side of the counter, where customers might line up to pay.

dialogues.speaker: COUNTER WOMAN
dialogues.text: -- so's it'd be what you call an impulse kind of purchase. This part of your story you're writing? Everett pauses a moment, looking around.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Nope. Good point. It's not part of the story I'm writing. I'm writing a human interest sidebar. Know what that is?

dialogues.speaker: COUNTER WOMAN
dialogues.text: I don't think I do.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: I don't think I do, either. Hey, thanks. He grins and goes out the door, which slams behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everett slams the door of his car as he gets out. The CAR keeps COUGHING and SPUTTERING as he glances at his watch: 12:50. He looks up at the small apartment building where he lives. There, at the bedroom window, is his wife BARBARA. She is young, elegant, even beautiful, but she looks hurt and surprised, as if someone had just slapped her across the face. She has pushed back a white curtain and is watching Everett approach. Their eyes meet. She does not smile. She lets the curtain fall and disappears.

dialogues.text: Barbara opens the door and lets Everett in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everett enters, raising his hands in apology. Barbara doesn't react.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Sorry. I got held up. (CONTINUED )

He takes a deep breath and moves toward the living room. There, in front of the TV, sits his 4-year-old daughter, KATE. At the sight of her dad, Kate turns away from her umpteenth viewing of Cats Don't Dance, and her chubby face blossoms into smiles. She climbs to her feet and runs toward her father.

dialogues.text: (on TV) That was Dale Porterhouse, an accountant with the firm of Smoke, no, I'm sorry, that's Stokes and Whitney, Stokes and Whitney. dialogues.text: No, no, Daddy. No talk on the phone. We go the zoo now.

Everett, on the phone, tries to concentrate on Porterhouse's number, but he's also glued to the TV and is keeping a wary eye on Kate as well. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.text: The number you requested, 555-0791 can be automatically dialed by pressing one, or saying 'yes' at the dial tone for an additional charge of... seventy-five cents. Kate runs to her and reaches up!-- she seems upset. Meanwhile, the TV BLARES.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: (looking hurt) Steve! What now? Everett holds up a finger. The PHONE is RINGING on the other end. On the television, Frederick Robertson, a stolid, impressive man in a cheap suit and tie, is talking.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERTSON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (on TV) Wilma, I don't think there's any such thing as justice in a case like this. Barbara shakes her head, goes to a cushioned chair by the window, and hoists Kate into her lap, where she puts her socks on, all the while glaring at Everett.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERTSON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (on TV) If you haven't gone through it I don't think you can understand what happens to a family when a child is taken from you in this terrible way...

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: (to Barbara) It's just a hunch. You know the way I get. It's!-- I've just gotta find out this one thing, and then!--

dialogues.speaker: TELEPHONE VOICE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Stokes and Whitney.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Yes, is Dale Porterhouse there, please?

dialogues.speaker: TELEPHONE VOICE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. Mr. Porterhouse is at lunch. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUE CRIME - Rev. 5/11/98 46.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERTSON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (on TV) For six years now, our whole life has been screwed up by this, this anger and rage. And nothing's going to end that rage except the death of that monster who killed my daughter and my unborn grandchild. Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: I got my shoes on now, Daddy! Now we can go to the zoo! Kate leaps off her mother's lap and runs to Everett, clutching at her father's pants leg. Everett, ever more distracted, pats her on the head. Barbara glares. The TV BLARES.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Could I leave a message? This is Steve Everett. I'm a reporter for the Oakland Tribune. Could you ask Mr. Porterhouse if he could call me as soon as he possibly can? It's in connection with the Beachum case.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Don't talk on the phone, Daddy. Don't talk on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: TELEPHONE VOICE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I'll let him know as soon as he comes in.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: I'll give you my beeper number.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: Steve! Please! Don't take your beeper!

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Don't talk on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: WILMA FRANCIS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (on TV) But should the state sanction a murder just to satisfy your rage, Mr. Robertson?

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: It's area code 510-555-1439.

dialogues.speaker: TELEPHONE VOICE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I'll make sure he gets that. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.text: (on TV) My daughter was shot in cold blood for no reason. For ninety-six dollars, and he took her ring and a locket I gave her for her sixteenth birthday. That wasn't aman who did that. That wasn't a human being. That was someone who doesn't deserve the same rights as a human being. Everett puts aside the phone and hoists Kate up in his arms.

dialogues.text: Are we going now?

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Yup! Here we go! Zoo time! Just gotta get something from the bedroom, come on, we're going.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: You're not. Everett heads for the bedroom with Kate in his arms; he calls back to Barbara as he walks.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: I just have to ask this guy one question. It's just a hunch. No big deal.

dialogues.text: Everett rifles the drawers for his beeper. In his arms, Kate keeps whapping him on the head as if it were a drum.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Daddy. Daddy. Daddy. Daddy.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: (distractedly) That's right. Yep. Okay, here it is. He finds the beeper in a bedside table and hooks it to his belt.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: What's that, Daddy? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.text: 47 48 49 TRUE CRIME - Rev. 5/11/98 48.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: That's Daddy's beeper. It goes beep, beep beep!-- you'll hear it. They go back into the living room.

dialogues.text: Kate keeps whapping Everett's head.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Beep beep beep. They head for the front door. Barbara watches, her arms crossed beneath her breasts. On the TV, Wilma Francis is talking.

dialogues.speaker: WILMA FRANCIS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (on TV) Strong words and strong emotions from murder victim dad Frederick Robertson. Stay with us for a different point of view. After a break we'll be talking to someone who thinks capital punishment is never the solution, no matter how violent and brutal the crime. After the break.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: (waving to Barbara) ‘Bye, Mommy. ‘Bye!

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: ‘Bye, sweetheart. Have a great time! Everett opens the door, looks back, cocks an eyebrow at Barbara. She purses her lips and turns away. Everett and Kate go out.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: (under his breath) Never should have stopped at that goddamn grocery. (to Kate) Right, kid?

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: (behind him) You have the car seat? Everett's face: oh no, the car seat. He hands Kate to Barbara.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everett struggles to attach a child seat in the back of the car. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 49 50 51 TRUE CRIME - Rev. 5/11/98 49,

dialogues.text: He is digging for an elusive seat belt, and as he does, he unearths all manner of garbage!-- old sandwiches, an empty Johnny Walker pint, newspapers, oil containers, greasy rags, a mystery garment, a second Johnnie Walker pint, this one containing a few remaining drops. Everett glances wistfully at the bottle and tosses it on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: (yelling to him) Is everything all right?

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: (yelling back) Just about got it. He reaches into the seat one more time, pulls out a blackened arm, and gives up. With a shrug, he grabs the solo seat belt strap, loops it around the child seat, and ties a knot. He shakes the seat. Loose as a goose and clearly a worthless fix.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT

dialogues.speaker: KATE

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Mr. Dale Porterhouse, please. It's Steve Everett of the Tribune. (to Kate) Shh. I'm sorry, darlin'. I have to do this. We'll get back to the zoo ina sec.

dialogues.text: We go to the zoo. Ina sec.

dialogues.speaker: PORTERHOUSE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Dale Porterhouse. What can I do for you? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUE CRIME - Rev. 5/11/98 50.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Hi! Steve Everett, from the Tribune. I'm covering the Frank Beachum execution today, and I know you were one of the chief witnesses.

dialogues.speaker: PORTERHOUSE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Yes. Yes, I was.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Daddy, why did it go beep beep beep?

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT

dialogues.text: Glad to. But I can't talk now. You want to meet somewhere?

dialogues.speaker: KATE

dialogues.text: What is wrong with you! He is about to reply, but she closes the door in his face. He stands for a moment, with a look on his face that says, "What is wrong with me?"

dialogues.speaker: SHOES 54
dialogues.text: -- CLACKING down the hall. First, a pair of standard- issue, black correctional-officer brogans. Following these, a pair of woman's open-toe sandals. Then, somewhat incongruously, a pair of shiny, black Mary Janes and white frilly socks. We also see the hem of a little girl's Sunday dress. The girl holds a drawing in one hand and a box of Crayolas, open at one end, in the other. Sounds of LOUD BOOM BOXES, TELEVISIONS, and caged, VIOLENT MEN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LEESHA MITCHELL, an overworked, black attorney in her late twenties, leans forward into a pile of backlogged briefs.

dialogues.speaker: LEESHA
dialogues.text: (on phone) How you holding up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beachum leans his head against the bars, phone in hand. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BEACHUM
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: LEESHA
dialogues.text: Like I said, there's always a chance. But you know, with all the feeling about the girl and all... An associate pops into Leesha's office carrying a large birthday cake. He gestures, "Where do you want it?" Leesha nods toward and end table. The associate points to his watch and slips out.

dialogues.speaker: LEESHA
dialogues.text: Here's the thing. You know how the governor's all tough on crime and so forth. So Mr. Berris says maybe if you can tell him about how remorseful you feel... know what I'm saying? Beachum dredges up four heavy words.

dialogues.speaker: BEACHUM
dialogues.text: I didn't do it.

dialogues.speaker: LEESHA
dialogues.text: I understand, I understand. I'm just telling you. That's what we're facing here, all right? The door to the Deathwatch cell is opening. In steps CO Atkins, followed by Frank's wife, Bonnie, and their seven-year-old daughter, Gail.

dialogues.speaker: BEACHUM
dialogues.text: (slowly, firmly) I can't say I'm sorry for what I never did. Gail breaks into an excited smile and runs to the bars of the cage. Bonnie follows, a little unsteadily, holding Beachum's eyes with hers, trying to smile but starting to cry.

dialogues.speaker: LEESHA
dialogues.text: No. Sure. Okay. Listen. I'11 call back when the appeal comes down, all right? Should be soon. We're not going to forget about you -- Frank has already dropped the phone, which swings freely from the wall. Reedy moves to replace it. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: Hi, Daddy. I brought you a picture but I'm not finished so I have to finish. Beachum clutches at his girls through the bars, fighting back tears, searching for strength.

dialogues.speaker: BEACHUM
dialogues.text: Hey, that's great, sugar. Justa minute, they'll let you in and I can have me a better look. Reedy disengages the electrical lock on the wall. Moving to the bars, he unlocks the mechanical. Everybody takes a small step back as the bars slide open. Gail bursts in first, wrapping herself around Frank's leg. He holds both their heads to his and breathes deeply.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHBACK
dialogues.text: Mowing his lawn. He stops and breathes deeply. Fresh grass, fresh air. Turning, he looks toward -- Bonnie barbecuing. She smiles and waves an empty bottle of A-1 Sauce. "We're out." Gail in the sandbox, whacking the sand with a shovel.

dialogues.speaker: BEACHUM
dialogues.text: (to Bonnie; indicating Gail) We're not sad about this. We're not afraid.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: Daddy, I'm going to finish my picture.

dialogues.speaker: BEACHUM
dialogues.text: Why don't you work right here while I have me a little talk with your mama. Beachum clears the small table for Gail. She puts her picture down and sets up the Crayola box. He kisses her on the head. Bonnie comes to him and falls into his arms. For a moment, she struggles against the tears, and then she lets them surge. Frank holds her, murmuring in her ear, fighting not to break down. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BEACHUM
dialogues.text: Come on, girl. Come on. I'm just going to dreamland, baby, that's all. Gonna set the table for you. Gonna be holding two places at the table for you. Over this, Gail is talking to him, brandishing her picture.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: Look, it's green pastures, Daddy. See? This is the blue sky. I made it at the motel. Daddy? It's not finished yet.

dialogues.speaker: BEACHUM
dialogues.text: (murmuring to Bonnie) We're not sad. We know there's a place beyond this place, don't we, baby? Bonnie finally pulls away and looks at him through her tears.

dialogues.speaker: BONNIE
dialogues.text: Okay, Frank. Okay.

dialogues.speaker: BEACHUM
dialogues.text: Thing I worry about, thing I worry about most in all this is -- His eyes go to Gail. She's going through her crayons, touching each one with the top of her finger, talking to herself.

dialogues.speaker: BONNIE
dialogues.text: She loves you, Frank.

dialogues.speaker: BEACHUM
dialogues.text: I don't want her ever to think, you know...

dialogues.speaker: BONNIE
dialogues.text: She won't think that. She knows you.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: I can't find green, Mama. Do you have it?

dialogues.speaker: BONNIE
dialogues.text: All the crayons are in the box, baby.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: (getting perturbed) Well, I can't find it. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BEACHUM
dialogues.text: (to Bonnie) Don't ever let her think it. You make sure now, okay?

dialogues.speaker: BONNIE
dialogues.text: I'll make sure, I swear.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: It's lost! I can't find it anywhere!

dialogues.speaker: BONNIE
dialogues.text: Can you use another color?

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: (crying now) I have to have green! It's green pastures!

dialogues.speaker: BEACHUM
dialogues.text: Well, let's look for it, it has to be around here...

dialogues.speaker: BONNIE
dialogues.text: I'm sure Daddy won't mind what colors you use.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: It has to be green! It has to be green! It's green pastures!

dialogues.speaker: BONNIE
dialogues.text: Gail, calm down.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Mrs. Beachum -- They turn to find Plunkitt facing them outside the bars.

dialogues.speaker: PLUNKITT
dialogues.text: What parking area did you use?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A prison guard searches an area around Bonnie's car. A second guard traces Bonnie's path toward the entrance. His eyes are focused on the ground. He taps a grass strip with a litter pole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reedy's PHONE RINGS. Beachum and Bonnie fall silent. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: REEDY
dialogues.text: (on phone) Just a moment. Frank --

dialogues.speaker: BONNIE
dialogues.text: Maybe it's the appeal. It must be. Don't you think? It's the, it's the appeal, the stay. Don't you think?

dialogues.speaker: REEDY
dialogues.text: Your lawyer again -- He moves to hand Beachum the phone. Beachum leans toward the bars and brings the phone to his ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two guards slowly walk toward us, their flashlights and eyes locked on the baseboards.

dialogues.speaker: LEESHA
dialogues.text: Frank --

dialogues.speaker: BEACHUM
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: LEESHA
dialogues.text: We lost it. I'm sorry. Beachum's stomach sinks. He clears his throat.

dialogues.speaker: BEACHUM
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of the GUARDS speaks into his walkie-talkie.

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: Control, I believe the material has been located. He holds a Crayola close to his face.  63 64 59.

dialogues.speaker: LEESHA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Now, Mr. Berris'll still be at the governor's desk late this afternoon, all right? But we gotta be honest about what's going on here, know what I'm saying?

dialogues.speaker: BEACHUM
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: LEESHA
dialogues.text: Frank... I'm really sorry, Frank. Beachum hands the phone back to Reedy. Bonnie watches him, waiting for an explanation, her wet eyes still hopeful. Gail bounces a look between the two as if sensing an event.

dialogues.speaker: BONNIE
dialogues.text: Is there... anything?

dialogues.speaker: BEACHUM
dialogues.text: No. No, nothing yet. You know these legal things, baby. Takes forever.

dialogues.speaker: REEDY
dialogues.text: Good news, everybody. They've found the crayon. It'll be here momentarily.

dialogues.speaker: BEACHUM
dialogues.text: You hear that, sugar? Now you can show me some real pastures.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: (uplifted) Green Pastures!

dialogues.speaker: BEACHUM
dialogues.text: That's right, baby. Green pastures!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A painting of green pastures, in fact, and of wheat being harvested. We are looking at the wall mural at the Bread Company Restaurant, a place where yuppies go to munch lunch. The CAMERA FINDS Steve Everett, who is sitting at a table with Dale Porterhouse. Porterhouse is wearing a suit.

dialogues.speaker: PORTERHOUSE
dialogues.text: I do think there's such a thing in this world as good citizenship. (MORE ) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: PORTERHOUSE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And I do think that when a man sees an injustice being done, let alone a cold- blooded murder --

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: You're not saying you saw the murder.

dialogues.speaker: PORTERHOUSE
dialogues.text: Of course not. I never said that.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: So what exactly did you see?

dialogues.speaker: PORTERHOUSE
dialogues.text: Look, I've been all through this a million --

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Sorry. I can't seem to put it all together in my head.

dialogues.speaker: PORTERHOUSE
dialogues.text: It's simple. I came in to use the phone -- my car had overheated. And soon as the door shut behind me, Beachum jumped up from behind the counter.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE EVERETT'S MIND
dialogues.text: We OVERCRANK, and Beachum rises from behind the counter, looking bloody, looking mean. He stares at Porterhouse, then runs out the door.

dialogues.speaker: PORTERHOUSE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: He was bloody all over, and he had a gun in his hand. I guess he had been bending over Amy, uh, Mrs. Wilson, and that must have been when he took her ring and necklace. Anyway, he got one look at me and ran out of the service entrance.

dialogues.speaker: PORTERHOUSE
dialogues.text: Shocked and dismayed. Now he runs over to the counter. We hear his BREATHING. He looks behind the counter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Behind the counter, Amy Wilson lies dead in a pool of blood. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PORTERHOUSE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: My first concern was the girl, so I immediately called 9-1-1 -- I figured rather than chase a killer with a gun, I'd let the police handle it.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: And they did.

dialogues.speaker: PORTERHOUSE
dialogues.text: And they sure did. As I say, we live by the rule of law in this country, and, uh -- aren't you going to take notes or record me or something? Usually when I've talked to reporters --

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Oh, I... have a photographic memory.

dialogues.speaker: PORTERHOUSE
dialogues.text: What? Are you kidding? Everett pulls a notebook and a Bic out of his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Sorry. Not myself today. Ate a bad oyster.

dialogues.speaker: PORTERHOUSE
dialogues.text: Yes. Well, my point was simply this... During his next speeches, Everett pretends to be writing in his notebook. Actually he is drawing something.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Can I just, do you mind if I just cut to the chase? Didn't you ever have any doubts? About your testimony?

dialogues.speaker: PORTERHOUSE
dialogues.text: Never. Why should I?

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: You definitely saw Frank Beachum's face. And the gun in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: PORTERHOUSE
dialogues.text: Obviously, if I'd had any doubt, I would have told the police. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Ooh, boy. Musta been scary. He was pointing the gun right at you? Everett makes a gun shape with his fingers and points it at Porterhouse. Porterhouse is a bit taken aback.

dialogues.speaker: PORTERHOUSE
dialogues.text: No. Thank God, no.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Waving it high in the air? Everett holds his hands over his head, bugs his eyes, and pretends to wave the gun.

dialogues.speaker: PORTERHOUSE
dialogues.text: Of course not. He had it down by his side in a very normal way.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Well, how could you see it over the potato chips? A pause -- just a split-second. Everett is staring into Porterhouse in a way we haven't seen before: his eyes are like lasers. He's not trying to spook Porterhouse, he's just looking into him, deep into him, searching out the truth.

dialogues.speaker: PORTERHOUSE
dialogues.text: I don't understand. What potato chips? I had a very clear view. Everett thrusts his notebook in front of Porterhouse. On the paper, he has sketched a rudimentary blueprint of the store -- the counter, the two doors, and the potato-chip rack that had left the white outlines on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sketch segues into an OVERHEAD SHOT of the store, and the CAMERA GLIDES DOWN TO the show what Everett is narrating:

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I mean, you came in, right? You saw Beachum stand up behind the counter, and you saw him run. But between you and the service entrance, well, see, that's where the potato-chip rack was. (MORE ) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And it just kind of seems to me you couldn't have seen the gun over that rack, if Beachum wasn't waving it in the air or something. Over this speech, we see Beachum running out the service door again, but this time the potato-chip rack stands between him and Porterhouse: Porterhouse can see Beachum only from the chest up. Plainly, no gun is visible.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT, (PRESENT)
dialogues.text: Still staring into Porterhouse. The CAMERA PULLS BACK to show:

dialogues.speaker: PORTERHOUSE
dialogues.text: Why would I say I saw the gun if I didn't?

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: You tell me. Maybe you felt good talking to the police, the reporters -- maybe you wanted to give them a little more than you really had. Maybe you wanted to be the man, tell the girls around the coffee machine --

dialogues.speaker: PORTERHOUSE
dialogues.text: (angry now) This is absurd! You think I would jeopardize a man's life to impress the people in my office? Everett looks at him, and knows that he has no real evidence. Nothing but those white outlines on the floor of Pocum's -- that, and what he saw for a nanosecond in Porterhouse's eyes.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: I don't know, Mr. Porterhouse. We only just met.

dialogues.speaker: PORTERHOUSE
dialogues.text: Listen, wise guy. I did a little research on you before I returned your call. You're the guy who did the big crusade to get that rapist released last year, that lying what's-his-name -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: (ruefully) You wouldn't be referring to Mike Vargas?

dialogues.speaker: PORTERHOUSE
dialogues.text: Yeah, you had the facts then, didn't you? Except when you threatened him with a D.N.A. test, he confessed. I'm surprised you didn't get fired on the spot, Mr. Everett.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Yeah. Me too. Everett takes a deep breath and rubs his eyes. He visibly sags: Is this another Mike Vargas case? Does he have anything, anything at all, to go on?

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Look, I'm sorry. I was out of line. I thought there was -- I don't know what I thought.

dialogues.speaker: PORTERHOUSE
dialogues.text: You're damn right you don't. And if you go to press with some pack of lies and innuendos, believe me!-- my lawyers will sue you and your paper so fast you won't know what hit you. Everett looks down at the table. The encounter is clearly over. A WAITRESS approaches.

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: May I tell you gentlemen about our specials today?

dialogues.speaker: SANDWICH 69
dialogues.text: wrapped in cellophane flying through the air. It plops on a folding table. We PULL BACK TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Plunkitt and his execution team sit around the table on a catwalk overlooking the main yard. Below, a few prisoners are milling around, lifting weights, smoking in small groups. ZACHARY PLATT is Plunkitt's deputy warden. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PLATT
dialogues.text: Who gets the roast beef?

dialogues.speaker: PLUNKITT
dialogues.text: Over here. Platt tosses a sandwich to Plunkitt. Arnold McCardle peeks under his rye bread. McCARDLE Seems like there's more fat and less meat every time I get this here.

dialogues.speaker: SKYCOCK
dialogues.text: Ain't that the way you order it, Arnold? Hold the meat, leave the fat.

dialogues.speaker: PLUNKITT
dialogues.text: Now, Arnold's all right. More of him, the better. Plunkitt looks around the table, proud of his team.

dialogues.speaker: PLUNKITT
dialogues.text: Okay, what do you say we do some work while we feed our faces? You all know that at eighteen hundred hours, the whole procedure staff meets here for a final briefing. And be advised --

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND SHILLERMAN
dialogues.text: Uh, 'scuse me, warden...

dialogues.speaker: PLUNKITT
dialogues.text: Right. Right. The Reverend Shillerman here'1ll be holding a prayer meeting at the end of the briefing which is optional for anyone who wants to stay. Atkins turns away and rolls his eyes. The others suppress guffaws. Attendance could be low.

dialogues.speaker: PLUNKITT
dialogues.text: Also, be advised, there's a change in the sixteen hundred interview thing. The girl had some accident or something and they're replacing her with a guy named Steve Everett.

dialogues.speaker: ATKINS
dialogues.text: Damn!

dialogues.speaker: PLUNKITT
dialogues.text: Now I realize his butt ain't quite up to the standard of Michelle's, but that's who's coming. Everybody clear on that?  70 71 72 66.

dialogues.speaker: AT EVERETT'S DESK
dialogues.text: Everett sits for a moment, lost in thought. He is staring at a photo of Beachum and a photo of Porterhouse, and he is wrestling with his doubts. Finally he smacks his fist on the desk, gets up, and starts walking toward Alan's office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob is staring malevolently as Everett strides toward Alan Mann's office. As Everett passes Jane, she looks up at him and then back down, shaking her head. Inside Alan's office we can see the editor talking with a very distinguished-looking, gray-haired man in an expensive suit. This is HENRY LOWENSTEIN, the newspaper's owner. Everett knocks on Alan's glass wall, and Alan motions him in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everett enters. Alan and Lowenstein rise.

dialogues.speaker: LOWENSTEIN
dialogues.text: Well, speak of the devil. Alan here tells me I'm paying you too much.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Yeah, but you can rest assured that I'm frittering it away on booze and girls.

dialogues.speaker: LOWENSTEIN
dialogues.text: (laughing) Hah! You're a dyed-in-the-wool sonuvabitch, Everett, anyone ever tell you that?

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Only my friends and loved ones. Hey, I didn't mean to interrupt. I can come back --

dialogues.speaker: LOWENSTEIN
dialogues.text: I was just leaving. Seriously -- still sober as a judge, right?

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: You obviously haven't partied with the sixth circuit court lately. But this time Lowenstein really is serious -- he wants an answer. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Yes, Mr. Lowenstein. Still sober as -- an ex-drunk.

dialogues.speaker: LOWENSTEIN
dialogues.text: Good to see you, Steve. Alan. He nods toward them both and leaves. Alan sits down and motions for Everett to do the same. Alan pulls a Snickers out of his drawer.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Stop fucking Bob's wife. He doesn't like it.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: What, did he put it in the company newsletter? Alan points his Snickers at Everett.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: If he comes to me and wants your ass, I'm gonna have to give it to him. Then you'll just be a hole with no ass around it. Everett pulls out a cigarette and lights it, hiding momentarily behind the flame. Alan bites his Snickers, gazing at Everett.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: You know what, Ev? You're a fucking womanizer, that's what. You're fucking up your whole career and you're fucking up your marriage and if you can't keep your goddamned prick in your pants I'm not gonna be able to goddamned protect you. How was she?

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: None of your goddamned business. Not bad.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Lucky bastard. I always liked her. I ever tell you about the assistant D.A. I fell for in New York?

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: No, and if you tell me now, I'm going to throw myself across your desk and rip your throat out with my bare hands. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 72  TRUE CRIME - Rev. 5/11/98 68.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: I'll save it for another time. Edifying story, though.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: I've got a problem.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Oh, the nickel finally drops. Christ, boy, don't you know Bob's been after you since you got here? In that quiet, earnest, reasonable way of his. He's probably glad you fucked Patricia so he has ethical reason to annihilate you.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Great. I live to make him happy. But that's not my problem.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: You should've fucked my wife. I'd've just punched you.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: I did fuck your wife.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Lucky bastard. How was she?

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Real wildcat. But that's not my goddamned problem, Alan.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: All right. What's your goddamned problem? Tell papa. You soulless sack of shit.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Frank Beachum. I think he could be innocent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The prison official pass a trash bag around the table.

dialogues.speaker: PLUNKITT
dialogues.text: After our briefing, Reuben and Pat are gonna be checking all the phones in the chamber, make sure we got the open lines working.

dialogues.speaker: SKYCOCK
dialogues.text: Don't want the Governor to get a busy signal. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ATKINS
dialogues.text: Don't worry, I got call waiting put on that phone. McCARDLE (giggling) Jesus, Atkins.

dialogues.speaker: PLUNKITT
dialogues.text: Arnold, you'll make sure the clocks in there are synchronized and the one in the press room, too. Norm, you've got the strap-down team, okay?

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND SHILLERMAN
dialogues.text: I, uh, I myself had a personal heart-to- heart with the prisoner myself this morning, and, going by my experience with the men, he won't be any trouble, in my opinion. Plunkitt fantasizes the hard point of his shoe making contact with Shillerman's ass. Just then, a shadow falls across the table. The men look up and go silent. Standing quietly above them is the executioner. He nods to the men. They nod back somberly, and we see their faces, one by one.

dialogues.speaker: ATKINS
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: SKYCOCK
dialogues.text: Joe. McCARDLE Hiya, Joe.

dialogues.speaker: PLUNKITT
dialogues.text: Joe. For a moment, nobody says a word.

dialogues.speaker: SNICKERS BAR 74
dialogues.text: sliding into Alan Mann's mouth.

dialogues.speaker: CIGARETTE
dialogues.text: being puffed by Everett. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alan chews mightily. Across from him, Everett smokes. They look at each other, two old friends enjoying a mock standoff.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: All right, all right. What have you got on Beachum? Everett lifts his cigarette hand as if to speak -- but what, indeed, has he got? He puts the filter to his lips and sucks hard. Alan watches him, shaking his head in mock horror.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Oh... oh, Ev.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: No, no, wait...

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Ev, CV, GV...

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Just listen to me a moment...

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Ev. I don't have to listen to you. I'm looking at you. I'm looking and I see a reporter who's about to tell me that he has a hunch.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Alan, I've done some checking up...

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Do you know my opinion of reporters who have hunches?

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: I talked to one of the witnesses, Alan. He says he saw a gun, but I know he didn't.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: I can't fart loud enough to express my opinion.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Alan, even Michelle knew this thing stinks. There are discrepancies. Alan brings his chair forward sharply. His eyes bug. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Discrepancies? Did I hear you say there were discrepancies? After a police investigation? A trial? Six years of appeals? You found discrepancies? What did it take you, half an hour?

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Come on. You know the appeals system. Beachum's first lawyer was probably some twelve-year-old Legal Aid guy, and if he didn't object to something at the trial, then the appeals guys had nothing to work with, no matter how sharp they were, which of course they weren't.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Ev...

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Alan, for Christ's sake, they're gonna kill this guy. Everett crushes out his cigarette and stares at Alan. Alan stares back. Finally, he sighs and grins ruefully.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: All right, all right. You're saying you can turn this routine execution piece into some kind of big fight-for-justice story. And that'll give me an excuse to stand up for you when Bob asks me to transfer you to the toilet.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: I need this one, Alan.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: You'll still lose the wife and kid, you know. She's gonna find out.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Don't say that. Don't even -- I gotta fix that. I'm gonna --

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: I don't have to tell you what'll happen if you pull another Mike Vargas on me, right? You come up with something, okay, I'll run it, but it'd better be good. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Look, I was drinking back then, all right? You drink, you lose your story nose. My nose is back. I'm sure of it.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: I guess we'll both find out.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: There's just one thing. What if I really find something, you know? We can't just wait for it to run tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Ev, I know what you're thinking. I can hear your little brain ticking -- I really can. And let me just remind you: if you go to Lowenstein thinking he'll call the governor --

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: The gov'll listen to Lowenstein.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: -- it better be awfully good. Or he not only won't call the governor, he'll eat your heart and throw your body to the dogs. You won't have to sleep with his wife, pal. He'll fire you for free.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Okay, Alan. Honest to God, I'm gonna... Anyway, thanks

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Hey, don't thank me. I don't know whose ass you're trying to save here, Beachum's or your own. But if your nose for a story's gone, you're gone, too. I'm not running this paper to salvage what's left of your smarmy little existence. So she was really pretty good, huh?

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Fuck you.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Lucky bastard. Everett laughs, gets up, gives Alan a look, laughs again. Alan starts whistling to himself. Everett leaves the office.  75 76 73.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everett makes a beeline for the supply room. In the b.g., we can see Bob watching him, giving him the evil eye. Everett looks at the clock.

dialogues.speaker: CLOCK
dialogues.text: It reads 2:50.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everett enters and begins scouting for pads. He grabs two from a pile and shoves them into his back pocket. He takes a couple of Bics and clips them to the pocket of his shirt. He turns. Bob Findley is standing in front of him, smiling a mirthless, pitying smile. Everett watches him in horror.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: You know, I don't know what to say to you. All day, I've been trying to think of what to say to you.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: I really am sorry, Bob. Really. I am.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: (a bitter laugh) You know, I really don't think you are. I actually don't think you're capable of feeling sorry. I don't think you're capable of feeling anything for others. This hits Everett unexpectedly hard.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: You might be right, Bob... I... you might be right. (beat) How'd you find out, anyway?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: She told me.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: She...?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Patricia saved some of your cigarette butts. Left them in an ashtray by her bed. That was her way of telling me. Another blow. For a moment, Everett is stunned. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Yeah. I guess that's all I was to her -- just a way of getting your attention. Bob, I don't know if it helps anything, but I feel like shit. I really -- feel like shit.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: You're right, Steve. It doesn't help anything at all. Bob exits, leaving Everett in the supply room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A uniformed female guard slips quietly into the cell and makes eye contact with Reedy.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL'S DRAWING
dialogues.text: A colorful, open landscape, now dominated by pine green.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beachum and Gail huddled closely on the cot.

dialogues.speaker: BEACHUM
dialogues.text: This is beautiful, baby. I'11 keep this with me always, all right?

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: Can we come back tomorrow? Can we stay at the motel again?

dialogues.speaker: BEACHUM
dialogues.text: Well, tomorrow morning you and Mama get to go back home.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: I don't want to go back. I want to stay with you. She begins to whimper and cry.

dialogues.speaker: BEACHUM
dialogues.text: Lookit, baby. You're a big girl. You know what's happening here, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: Yes...

dialogues.speaker: BEACHUM
dialogues.text: You know, after today... after today, you won't be able to see your daddy no more. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Gail suddenly buries her face in his shoulder. He holds her, breathing her in. Bonnie turns toward the wall, sobbing.

dialogues.speaker: BEACHUM
dialogues.text: But I'll be there, baby. I will. Listen to me, okay? You'll always be able to talk to me. All right? Remember, we talked about the baby Jesus? Well, I'll be up with Him. I'll be watching you, and I'll wait for you. And any time you need to talk, I'll be right there, listening. And -- He stifles a sob.

dialogues.speaker: BEACHUM
dialogues.text: -- and I'll miss you so bad, honey. (beat) Look. I wrote you a letter... He reaches for it, but Gail's face shows she doesn't understand.

dialogues.speaker: BEACHUM
dialogues.text: Your mama will have it for when you need it, later on. So you go on now. I love you, baby. I'1l always love you. Beachum gently delivers Gail to the female guard. He's trying desperately not to choke up as Gail follows the guard meekly for a few steps before turning back --

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: Why can't you just come home? You should just kill all these people and come home! The guard starts to pull her away. Beachum puts an arm over his face -- this is more than he can bear. Bonnie holds her face in her hands, sobbing. The door closes, but we can still hear her shrill little voice.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Goodbye, Daddy! Goodbye, Daddy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car is rocketing along at a rate far beyond its apparent aerodynamic capabilities. Blue smoke plumes from the tailpipe. Inside, Everett is revved up. On the RADIO, ELVIS sings “Jailhouse Rock." Everett bangs the dashboard and sings along.  79 80 81 82 83 76.

dialogues.speaker: DAY 79
dialogues.text: It looms over the horizon, a sobering hulk of gray stone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everett's car passes a growing crowd of protestors and death-penalty advocates camped out at the gate. It's a macabre tailgate party. Everett glances at the "Remember Amy" posters.

dialogues.speaker: FEATURING POSTERS
dialogues.text: The same photo of Amy Wilson that we have seen on TV -- the drab blouse, the gold locket, the mousy brown hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAR pulls in, COUGHING blue smoke. It shudders for a moment after Everett TURNS OFF the ENGINE. He gets out. A very old steak, still in its supermarket packaging, thuds to the ground as he steps out. He looks at it curiously for a moment -- When did he intend to cook it? How drunk was he? -- and then he picks it up. It seems to be oozing. Gingerly, Everett tosses it in the back seat. He heads for the prison.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thick concrete walls. Sound of BARS CLANKING shut. Everett follows Atkins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everett glances at each passing cell.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: (to Atkins) Nice place. Remind me never to commit a violent crime.

dialogues.speaker: ATKINS
dialogues.text: (deadpan) They lie, you know.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ATKINS
dialogues.text: The prisoners. That's what they do. Every word they say is a lie.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Everyone lies, pal. I'm just here to write it down.  84 TRUE CRIME - Rev. 5/11/98 77.

dialogues.speaker: REEDY
