dialogues.text: He types in the chronological: "16:04 -- reporter arrives for interview." Then he looks up at Everett, who is looking down at him.

dialogues.speaker: REEDY
dialogues.text: You've got fifteen minutes, Mr. Everett. By order of Warden Plunkitt. Keep it to fifteen minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beachum moves toward the bars. His face is marked by a profound weariness. He looks drained, hollowed out, almost spectral. Now Bonnie rises up behind him and moves toward the bars too, her hand clutching Beachum's, the knuckles white.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Reedy pulls up a chair in front of the cell for Everett. Beachum sticks his hand through the cell, and Everett shakes it.

dialogues.speaker: BEACHUM
dialogues.text: Mr. Everett, I'm Frank Beachum. Have a... He gestures toward the chair.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Yeah. Thanks. Everett sits and pulls out his notebook and pen. Beachum gently disengages himself from Bonnie and lowers himself into the chair at the table in front of Everett. Bonnie sinks back down onto the cot, her eyes on Everett. Everett fiddles for a cigarette, jerks one halfway out of the pack, and offers it to Beachum.

dialogues.speaker: BEACHUM
dialogues.text: I got ‘em. They light up, and then they smoke for a long, awkward moment.

dialogues.speaker: BEACHUM
dialogues.text: How's... that girl? That other, that Michelle. She had some accident?

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Yeah. Car crash. She's... she didn't make it. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BEACHUM
dialogues.text: Oh, man. I'm sorry to hear that.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Yeah. She was... yeah. Thanks. Another awkward silence. They smoke.

dialogues.speaker: BEACHUM
dialogues.text: Well... I guess you want to talk to me about how it feels. In here.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Yeah, that's it. It's a human interest story. Everett watches the long, sad, tired face pushing the words out at him through the bars, through the smoke.

dialogues.speaker: BEACHUM
dialogues.text: (his voice flat) I been thinking about that. Hey, look what my daughter drew me. My daughter Gail. Calls it 'Green Pastures.' Beachum shows him the drawing. Everett tries to look interested.

dialogues.speaker: BEACHUM
dialogues.text: Well, only thing I want to say, I wanted to tell everyone that I believe in Jesus Christ. Our Lord and Savior. Everett scribbles dutifully on his pad: "B'lieve in JC, Lord + Sav..."

dialogues.speaker: BEACHUM
dialogues.text: And I believe... I'm going to a better place and there's a better justice there, you know, and... I won't say I'm not afraid ‘cause I think... A loud sob from Bonnie, who is sitting on the cot.

dialogues.speaker: BEACHUM
dialogues.text: .-». ‘cause I think everyone's afraid of dying pretty much. I came to my faith late in life, you know. I done some bad things when I was younger, but that was then, you know. Anyway, I know the crooked will be made straight -- that's what the Bible says, and I believe that. Everett scribbles: "crooked made straight." (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BEACHUM
dialogues.text: So that's how I feel about it. He looks at Everett, but for some reason Everett can't manage to look back. Everett just keeps staring down at his pad.

dialogues.speaker: BEACHUM
dialogues.text: Is that all right, Mr. Everett? Everett can't look at him. He glances over at Reedy.

dialogues.speaker: REEDY
dialogues.text: You got nine more minutes.

dialogues.speaker: BEACHUM
dialogues.text: Is that what you wanted or... Everett finally looks up, blowing a stream of smoke in an unsteady breath. He leans forward, forcing himself to look at this condemned, roiling man living out his last hours -- the pain in that face, and the toil. Bonnie looks up, watching Everett.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Mr. Beachum... You don't know me, Mr. Beachum, but I'1l tell you, I probably got a screw loose somewhere. To tell you the truth, I don't give a rat's ass about Jesus Christ. And I don't care about justice, in this life or the next. To be honest, I don't even care about what's right and wrong. Never have. Everett drops his cigarette to the floor and rubs it out with his shoe. Beachum and Bonnie are watching him, mesmerized. Everett taps his nose.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: You know what this is?

dialogues.speaker: BEACHUM
dialogues.text: Is this some kind of joke?

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: It's no joke, Mr. Beachum. It's my nose. And my nose -- well, to tell you the pitiful truth, it's my whole goddamn life. When my nose says something stinks, I gotta have faith in it, just like you have your faith in Jesus. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: When it's working, I know there's truth out there somewhere. But if it leads me astray, well, I may as well drive off a cliff... I really -- I'm nothing. The point is, lately I'm not a hundred percent positive my nose is working right. So I have to know. Did you kill that woman or not?

dialogues.speaker: BEACHUM
dialogues.text: (dully, disbelieving) What? What happened,

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: dammit? In that store. The day Amy Wilson was shot. The two men stare at each other. We see that Everett is looking right into Beachum, the way he looked right into Porterhouse.

dialogues.speaker: BEACHUM
dialogues.text: I... went in to buy a bottle of A-1 Sauce.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: And you paid Amy for it at the counter.

dialogues.speaker: BEACHUM
dialogues.text: Well, no, I never got it. Look, I told them all this --

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Tell it again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beachum enters through behind the counter, is

dialogues.speaker: DAY 85
dialogues.text: the main door. To his left, Amy.

dialogues.speaker: BEACHUM
dialogues.text: Hey, Amy. Where you keep the steak sauce?

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Hi, Frank. It's back, you see where the ketchup and relish is? Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: BEACHUM
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He starts to go, but when Amy calls to him he approaches the counter.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Frank, you know I been meaning to talk to you.

dialogues.speaker: BEACHUM
dialogues.text: Yeah. I bet I know what about.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: I don't got it, Frank. I could pay you thirty now. But I don't got the whole thing.

dialogues.speaker: BEACHUM
dialogues.text: When could you do the whole ninety-six?

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: After I get paid, fifteenth of July.

dialogues.speaker: BEACHUM
dialogues.text: You're not always gonna do me this way, are you?

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: I swear it, Frank. We just had some extra expenses, end of the school year and all.

dialogues.speaker: BEACHUM
dialogues.text: It's cool. July fifteenth. Hey, I'm just gonna use the bathroom, okay?

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: You know where, right? Beachum nods and heads toward the back of the store. The bathroom is in a small entryway, and as Beachum heads toward it, we hear the front DOOR SLAM. Beachum struggles for a moment with the sticky bathroom door and goes in.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: So you weren't even mad about the money?

dialogues.speaker: BEACHUM
dialogues.text: Well, I wanted her to understand I didn't like doing business that way. But she was cool. I liked her. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 86 87 88 TRUE CRIME - Rev. 5/11/98 82.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Were you carrying a gun?

dialogues.speaker: BEACHUM
dialogues.text: No way, man.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: So then what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beachum is standing in the stall (it's a one-toilet bathroom), humming to himself. We hear MUFFLED VOICES outside, and at first Beachum doesn't notice them. He finishes and FLUSHES the TOILET. Over the sound of the flush, the VOICES GROW LOUDER. Beachum can't be sure what he's hearing. Then he hears Amy's anguished voice!--

dialogues.speaker: AMY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Please! Not that! -- followed by a GUNSHOT. For a moment, Beachum stands paralyzed. Then he bolts out of the stall, pushes at the sticky bathroom door, kicks it open, runs down the small entryway, and emerges into the main body of the store.

dialogues.speaker: DAY 88
dialogues.text: The door to the service entrance is slamming. There's no one else in sight. Beachum runs toward the counter; behind it, Amy Wilson is lying on her back, her eyes wide, her chest torn open by a bullet, the last breaths rattling out of her. Outside, very distantly, the sound of a CAR DOOR being SLAMMED, and then the SCREECH of TIRES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beachum falls to his knees by Amy's side, trying everything he can think of, making up his own brand of CPR as he goes along -- thumping her chest, breathing into her mouth, trying to staunch the blood with his hands, calling her name. Blood soaks his shirt, splatters onto his face, runs down his fingers. Amy looks into his eyes, terrified, and then her eyes go blank. Dimly, he hears the FRONT DOOR CLOSE. And a voice:

dialogues.speaker: PORTERHOUSE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hey! Anybody here? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Beachum pops up from behind the counter. Porterhouse's jaw drops.

dialogues.speaker: PORTERHOUSE
dialogues.text: Hey! What's going on? Oh my God! For a moment, he and Beachum stare at each other, and then, for another split second, Beachum looks down at himself, realizes how all this must seem, and bolts for the service door. We see clearly that the potato chip rack stands between him and Porterhouse.

dialogues.speaker: DAY 89
dialogues.text: He is RUNNING OUT the service door INTO a small passageway full of garbage cans, fire extinguishers, boxes and crates. OUT the outer screen door, RUNNING -- and wham! Nancy Larson's car nearly backs into him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beachum looks up, and we see Larson's eyes looking back, startled, from her rear-view mirror. Then Beachum runs out of the parking lot.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: "Please, not that.'

dialogues.speaker: BEACHUM
dialogues.text: ‘swhat I heard. Everett pops a cigarette into his mouth, never taking his gaze off Beachum's face.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Why'd you run?

dialogues.speaker: BEACHUM
dialogues.text: I shouldn't have. But you know, I'ma two-time loser, Mr. Everett. And there I was with all that blood and a dead girl right next to me and a white man staring at me like I was -- I just panicked.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: So who shot her, Frank? Bonnie gasps. She is staring at Everett. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BEACHUM
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Did Porterhouse see the gun?

dialogues.speaker: REEDY
dialogues.text: (threateningly) You got five minutes, over there.

dialogues.speaker: BEACHUM
dialogues.text: I told you. Wasn't no gun.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Did he see the shooter?

dialogues.speaker: BEACHUM
dialogues.text: I don't know. How should I know?

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Of course he didn't. ‘Cause by the time he pulled into the parking lot, the shooter was gone. That's why he didn't hear the shots, either.

dialogues.speaker: REEDY
dialogues.text: Mr. Everett...

dialogues.speaker: BEACHUM
dialogues.text: I don't know. I don't know when anything happened.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: ‘Cause you don't know how long you were down on the floor trying to save Amy's life. Bonnie sobs, but Everett ignores her. Beachum begins to slump and look away, but Everett only grows more intent. In the b.g., Reedy picks up the phone and talks anxiously into it. He never takes his eyes off Everett.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: So what was it, Frank, a simple robbery? Who else could have been there? Come on, Frank. Someone have something against her?

dialogues.speaker: BEACHUM
dialogues.text: I just don't know. I didn't see.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: (bearing down on him) Come on, give me something. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: BEACHUM
dialogues.text: (worked up) I don't know what you want. Reedy squeaks his chair and stands up.

dialogues.speaker: REEDY
dialogues.text: All right, that's it. Bonnie flings herself off the bed and rushes toward the bars.

dialogues.speaker: BONNIE
dialogues.text: No! Everett looks at her desperate, tear-stained face, but already Reedy is grabbing him, moving him forcefully away.

dialogues.speaker: BONNIE
dialogues.text: You believe us. Don't you? Do you believe us?

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: (to Reedy) All right, all right.

dialogues.speaker: REEDY
dialogues.text: Let's go. Upsetting people...

dialogues.speaker: BONNIE
dialogues.text: Do. You. Believe. Us?

dialogues.speaker: BEACHUM
dialogues.text: Don't, Bonnie. Don't.

dialogues.speaker: REEDY
dialogues.text: Come on, dammit. For a moment, everything stops. Everett stares at Bonnie and Bonnie stares back.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Yes. I believe you. For Christ's sake. Bonnie closes her eyes and begins weeping against the bars. Reedy pulls Everett toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: All right, dammit.

dialogues.speaker: REEDY
dialogues.text: Coming in here, upsetting people. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUE CRIME - Rev. 5/11/98 86.

dialogues.speaker: REEDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Where's your goddamn heart, man? Don't you think these people have enough? What do you think this is?

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: All right. Sorry. Yeah. They are at the door, but now Everett looks back. Bonnie is staring at him the way you'd look at a child who had just done something thoughtless and cruel.

dialogues.speaker: BONNIE
dialogues.text: Where were you? Dear God, where were you all this time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reedy starts to move Everett out, but Everett resists.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: It wasn't my story. There was an accident -- It wasn't supposed to be my story. Reedy pushes Everett out into the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Reedy pushes Everett into the corridor, Plunkitt is waiting for him. He looks quizzically at Everett and holds out his hand.

dialogues.speaker: PLUNKITT
dialogues.text: (shaking hands) Everett.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Warden. Good to see you again.

dialogues.speaker: PLUNKITT
dialogues.text: (gently) I'll walk you to your car. They walk.

dialogues.speaker: PLUNKITT
dialogues.text: Terrible about Ms. Ziegler.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Yeah. Horrible thing.

dialogues.speaker: PLUNKITT
dialogues.text: You know, she gave me to understand that she wanted to talk to Beachum about, you know, his emotions before the execution. (MORE ) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: PLUNKITT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Human interest stuff. ‘Cause otherwise, we do most press interviews by phone at this point. Less risk of upsetting the prisoner.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Yeah. I probably should have prepared better. Kind of a last-minute thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Plunkitt accompanies Everett toward his (Everett's) car.

dialogues.speaker: PLUNKITT
dialogues.text: You know, people come in here, the press. Prisoners tell ‘em things!-- all kind of heart-wrenching things. And then the next day, in the paper, we're the ones who come off sounding like hard guys. It can get pretty frustrating, is all.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Sure. Of course.

dialogues.speaker: PLUNKITT
dialogues.text: We have to do what the state tells us to do. Makes it a little tough on us here if we show up in the newspaper as bloody murderers or anything like that.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Right. I understand completely.

dialogues.speaker: PLUNKITT
dialogues.text: Knew you would. (beat) You know, these things go through all kind of trials and appeals before they get to us. It's no use trying to figure out who's naughty and who's nice and then come sliding down the chimney like a hero -- not on execution day. You're not Santa Claus. No such thing as Santa Claus. They reach the car. Plunkitt seems as though he wants to say something else, but instead he just stands there.

dialogues.speaker: PLUNKITT
dialogues.text: Well... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Everett looks at him expectantly, but Plunkitt can't find the words. Suddenly, Everett's expression changes.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: You're not sure, are you, Luther? Plunkitt looks at Everett for a long moment, then slaps his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: PLUNKITT
dialogues.text: You drive safe now. Plunkitt turns and walks back toward the prison doors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CECILIA NUSSBAUM, circuit attorney, comes out the formal door and starts down a series of long stone steps. She's a small, ugly woman with a big, fleshy beezer sticking out of a face that resembles a collection of frowns all glued on top of one another. She's accompanied by WALLY CARTWRIGHT, an imposing black attorney in a concrete-gray suit. Everett bounds up to them.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Cecilia! Nussbaum and Cartwright look but never break stride.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Wait. This is urgent.

dialogues.speaker: NUSSBAUM
dialogues.text: Not a good time, Everett.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: I know you're busy, but -- Cartwright crosses laterally like a good linebacker. Everett is shoved off-course. He staggers a step to the side.

dialogues.speaker: NUSSBAUM
dialogues.text: Not now. Call my office.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Cecilia, I'm telling you -- He reaches out to slow her. Cartwright pokes him in the chest.

dialogues.speaker: CARTWRIGHT
dialogues.text: Look... Everett knocks the finger away. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Oh, bullshit. You're a fucking circuit attorney, I'm a reporter. You wanna hit me or you wanna keep your job?

dialogues.speaker: NUSSBAUM
dialogues.text: Why don't you get in the car, Wally?

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Yeah, why don't you get in the car, Wally. Cartwright wavers a moment, and then moves toward the car.

dialogues.speaker: CARTWRIGHT
dialogues.text: (murmuring) New York asshole.

dialogues.speaker: NUSSBAUM
dialogues.text: What is it, Everett?

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: (still fuming) All right. Frank Beachum. Who else was there?

dialogues.speaker: NUSSBAUM
dialogues.text: Are you back on the bottle?

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: When Amy Wilson was killed, who else was there? Porterhouse, Nancy Larson, Beachum. And who else? Once again, Everett's eyes have become a laser beam. He is watching Cecilia's eyes the way he watched Porterhouse's eyes and Frank Beachum's eyes. Cecilia's eyes are very still.

dialogues.speaker: NUSSBAUM
dialogues.text: What difference does it make? Everett's face: He knows he's right.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: He's the shooter, Cecilia. Whoever he was, he shot Amy. Who was he? Come on.

dialogues.speaker: NUSSBAUM
dialogues.text: Everett, I don't know what kind of cockamamie conspiracy theory you're working on, but this is a solid case. I don't send innocent men to the Death House. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: I know that, I do. But this time you made a mistake. Sitting in the Cadillac, Cartwright HONKS the HORN. Without even looking up, Nussbaum holds up her index finger.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Beachum was in the bathroom when Amy got shot. He only went to Pocum's to buy a bottle of steak sauce.

dialogues.speaker: NUSSBAUM
dialogues.text: You've always been a gullible sonuvabitch, Everett. Read the transcripts. A witness saw Beachum with the gun.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: He didn't see the gun. There were potato chips in the way.

dialogues.speaker: NUSSBAUM
dialogues.text: You're telling me he said that.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: No. But I could see it in his face. I could tell. Nussbaum's face changes to a mask of leathery disdain.

dialogues.speaker: NUSSBAUM
dialogues.text: You haven't got jackshit.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: He didn't do it! How much jackshit do I need? Nussbaum studies him for a second and then begins heading down the stairs toward her car. Everett follows.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: There was someone else, wasn't there?

dialogues.speaker: NUSSBAUM
dialogues.text: (without looking back) A kid. Bought a Coke from the machine. He didn't even look inside.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: He shot Amy Wilson. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NUSSBAUM
dialogues.text: We interviewed him. We issued a description of his car and he came in of his own free will. His story checked out. He didn't see a thing.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: He shot her! You didn't get him to say anything because you had already arrested Beachum -- you thought you had the guy. But the kid was the guy! Nussbaum reaches the car. Everett thrusts himself between her and the door.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Tell me his name.

dialogues.speaker: NUSSBAUM
dialogues.text: He was nothing to the case. We put him in the same lineup Beachum was in. Both our witnesses looked right at him and still fingered Beachum as the killer. She looks at Everett triumphantly -- and indeed, for a moment, Everett is shaken. But he quickly recovers.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Okay, but what do you expect? Your witnesses didn't even get there till the shooter was long gone. Look, just give me the kid's name. Let me talk to him.

dialogues.speaker: NUSSBAUM
dialogues.text: How'm I supposed to remember his name after six years? He was nothing to the case.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: It's in your files, your notes. Somewhere.

dialogues.speaker: NUSSBAUM
dialogues.text: (opening the car door) Call me tomorrow. I'1l see if I can find it. She begins to get into the car, but Everett grabs the door, drawing it back -- and her with it. Everett is burning with rage. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: If you let it wait till tomorrow, then you better sleep goddamn well tonight. ‘Cause after today, I'm gonna haunt you, lady. I'm gonna hound the living shit out of you. Nussbaum lets the door go and turns to face Everett. She is not large, but she looks utterly terrifying.

dialogues.speaker: NUSSBAUM
dialogues.text: (too quietly) I'm not Wally, Steve. I'ma lot bigger than Wally. And if you threaten me again, there'll be little pieces of your life all over the gutter. ‘Cause I'll blow the rest away. Everett stares at her. She shuts the door with a heavy thud. Wally is about to drive away when Nussbaum opens the car window.

dialogues.speaker: NUSSBAUM
dialogues.text: One more thing, barfly. Just thought you oughta know before your latest lost cause confesses. Anyone ever tell you that Beachum volunteered for a lie detector test? Yeah. He flunked, big time. Sure, it's inadmissible -- that's why you didn't read about it in the transcripts. Still, it kind of captured our interest. Why don't you go pour yourself a tall one and think it over? Everett stares at her. The car speeds off. For a moment, Everett crumbles. He sits down on the steps of the courthouse and puts his head in his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Everett walks in, he sees Bob Findley smiling at him!-- a tight, terrible little smile that says: I have you by the balls. Everett goes to his desk, turns on his computer, and unwraps a ham sandwich. He lets out a long sigh. At the desk next to him, TOM DONALDSON, a plump reporter in his forties, rolls his chair over. He holds a glass of Scotch.

dialogues.speaker: DONALDSON
dialogues.text: Hey, Ev. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Everett nods. For a moment he looks longingly at the Scotch. Donaldson notices.

dialogues.speaker: DONALDSON
dialogues.text: Hey, you want a nip? Everett's eyes say yes, but then he shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: No. Thanks, Tom, I don't think I better.

dialogues.speaker: DONALDSON
dialogues.text: Sorry, Ev. I forgot. Hey, what's with you and Bob? He's been giving you the evil eye all day.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Yeah, and you know what? It's working.

dialogues.speaker: DONALDSON
dialogues.text: No, really -- did something happen at the prison? Some big uproar?

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Tell me something, Tom. Why would a guilty man volunteer for a lie detector test?

dialogues.speaker: DONALDSON
dialogues.text: Happens all the time. Perp gets cocky, thinks he can slide one by. Course, innocent men flunk 'em sometimes, too. Why? Bob want you to take one?

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: There's a cute idea. No, I don't think my guilt's in any doubt. Hey, is Bridget still here? I was going to try and get her to do some scutwork for me. Women are feeling more secure these days, you know.

dialogues.speaker: DONALDSON
dialogues.text: She went home. But I'll get you a cup of coffee if you'll give me head.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Cool. Could you see if you can track down any of the detectives who worked the Beachum case? See if anyone ever heard of another witness at the murder scene -- a kid. I just need a name and address. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the other end of the room, Alan is opening his office door to look out. And Bob is standing up from the city desk, ready to join the attack.

dialogues.speaker: DONALDSON
dialogues.text: You got it.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: And, Tom. Could you get me a cup of coffee? Donaldson blows him a kiss and walks away. Everett picks up the phone and punches in some numbers. He gives Alan a friendly wave. Alan glances at Bob, who returns the glance. Alan goes back in his office. Bob sits back down at his desk.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (on phone) Legal Services.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: It's Steve Everett at the Tribune. Who can talk to me about Beachum.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: All of us. Anyone here.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Okay. Before Beachum goes in the store, a kid drives into the parking lot. Right?

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Wrong. Anyway, there's nothing like that in the files.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: How do you know? Aren't you gonna check?

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: (laughing) Believe me, Mr. Everett, we all know. Everybody here has memorized these files the last two weeks. There are no other witnesses. Porterhouse, Larson -- that's it. But a lot of circumstantial on top of that. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: (sighing) Right. Okay. Thanks anyway. Everett hangs up the phone and looks at Donaldson. Donaldson shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Shit. Alan's door opens again. Alan steps out.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Shit.

dialogues.speaker: DONALDSON
dialogues.text: (hanging up) That was Benning, the whip on the investigation. Says it rings a bell, but turned out to be nothing. Doesn't remember any names.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Shit.

dialogues.speaker: DONALDSON
dialogues.text: And Ardsley, who headed the investigation, he's retired. Florida somewhere.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Shit.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: (from across the room) Everett! Get in here.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Shit. Everett sees Bob rise and head toward Alan's office. Everett walks across the big room. It's a long walk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alan waves Everett inside, and Bob comes in behind him, smiling his tight, satisfied little smile.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: (to Bob) Well, you don't have to look so happy about it. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I'm not happy. Why would you say that? Alan sits down and rubs his forehead.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: I understand your interview at the prison went somewhat beyond the requirements of a human interest sidebar. Everett grabs his cigarettes and shoots one into his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Okay. I colored outside the lines a little. I don't think Plunkitt's sore. Everett lights the cigarette and draws hard on it.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: No, Steve. He just figured you were back on the booze. And by the way, there's no smoking in this building.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Boys, boys. Come on. I can't have this. Everett, say you're sorry. Bob, punch his lights out.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: (looking surprised) This isn't a personal matter, Alan. This was an important story. I gave Steve very specific instructions on this. The paper made promises to Plunkitt...

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: The guy's innocent!

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: (rolling his eyes) Oh.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: (angrily) He is! Bob, it's not a human interest sidebar. It's a cruci-fucking-fiction, man! What did you want me to say to him, how's the weather up there, Mr. Christ? Everett pulls out his notebook and slaps it on the desk. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Look, I got all that personal crap you wanted. He believes in God. He's going straight to heaven. He's happy as a pig in shit, all right? He can't wait to be juiced. You can use that in the sidebar.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: (more in sorrow than anger ) That's not the point.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: You bet it's not the point.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Well, look. We'll take Everett off the execution and put Harvey on it instead.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Fine. But that's still not the point.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, we all know what the point is.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: (very deliberately) The only point is that I can't work with you anymore, Steve. Maybe you're a good reporter. Everyone says so. But there are other good reporters and they don't have your attitude and they follow instructions. I can't work with you. Alan lets out a low moan. Everett smokes, studying the floor. Bob gazes at him righteously. Then Everett explodes.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Why don't you just hit me, Bob? I deserve it. I'll fall down. I'll bleed. You'll love it. It'll be great. Punch me out, man. (beat) Then you can go home and hit your wife, too. She likes it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob's head goes back a little, but he retains his icy calm. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I guess we can't all live in the world of your imagination, Steve. I'm not going to hit anybody, no matter what they want. If Patricia needs some other kind of relationship, she'll have to go find that. But my marriage is none of your business. What matters is that you're a thoughtless, mentally unbalanced man, and I can't work with you anymore. Alan moans again, covering his eyes with his hand. Suddenly, Everett realizes that he's losing his job. He turns to Alan.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Alan, listen. I've got the shooter.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: (lowering his hand) You what?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I don't think we should confuse two separate issues.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: I got the guy who shot Amy Wilson.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Look, even if he knows who shot Kennedy! --

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Shut up, Bob. How have you got him?

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: I know who he is.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: All right. Who is he?

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: He's... he's a guy. A guy who was there. Alan pinches the bridge of his nose and closes his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: You're telling me the shooter was a guy who was there? Good work, Steve. Should I hold the front page or do you wanna get two unnamed sources on it? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: I'm telling you. The C.A., Nussbaum, has his name. She just won't give it to me.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: What about the defense?

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: I checked. It's not in their files.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: This is ridiculous.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: The cops?

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Don't remember. Or they're sitting on it.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Have you tried the Yellow Pages? Under Ss? Everett angrily stubs out his cigarette and turns toward the window. Bob moves toward the desk, a mournful look on his face.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Alan, I'm sorry. I really am. I know this is causing problems for everybody, but I want to be clear about this. I'm ready to leave. I love this paper, but I'm not going to spend my life in an environment that has become intolerable. Everett watches the traffic. The buses are still rolling. People still go about their business.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Inspiration hits. His eyes light up. He whirls around.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: You have to give me notice, Alan.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: It's in my contract. You can't just axe me. You have to give me notice. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Just how much notice do you want, Steve? Everett looks up at the clock. We see it, too: 5:53.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Six hours and seven minutes.

dialogues.speaker: SAN QUENTIN STATE PRISON
dialogues.text: A large, red sun slips behind a guard tower. INT. STORAGE ROOM - ADJOINING EXECUTION CHAMBER — 97

dialogues.speaker: RED PHONE
dialogues.text: with a taped label stuck to its base. McCardle picks up the headset. McCARDLE Testing red... testing red... He replaces the receiver and moves to a tan phone labeled “Communications Room." We notice two other phones, one white (Corrections Dept.) and one black (Governor's Office). McCARDLE Testing tan... We're testing tan... A worker sprays Windex on a window facing the chamber. We MOVE PAST him INTO the chamber, where two members of the strap-down team inspect the gurney. McCARDLE (0.S.) Moving to white... Reuben Skycock tests the injection machine. He works at a metal cabinet that contains three syringes. As he does we:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everett is zooming along, his RADIO ON the NEWS.

dialogues.speaker: RADIO REPORTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: .+. The first syringe will deliver five grams of sodium pentothal, and that will basically put him to sleep within a matter of a few seconds, we're told. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: RADIO REPORTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Then the line will be flushed with twenty CCs of saline solution, and then he will be given fifty CCs of pancuronium bromide. Now that is a muscle paralyzer, and his muscles will be paralyzed at that point -- he won't be able to breathe. And finally, fifty CCs of potassium chloride, and that'll stop his heart. We talked with Prison Doctor Roger Waters earlier today.

dialogues.speaker: DR. WATERS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: (on the radio) It should be a very pleasant, a very rapid sleep, and then the prisoner will know nothing else after that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over the preceding: Skycock testing the syringes. We see each syringe as the radio reporter mentions it. The CAMERA CONTINUES TO ROAM THROUGH the prison as we hear EVERETT'S RADIO IN V.O. We see:

dialogues.speaker: PLUNKITT
dialogues.text: 100 conferring with Dr. Waters.

dialogues.speaker: OTHER PRISONERS IN OPEN AREA 101
dialogues.text: Watching TV. Thanks, Terry.

dialogues.speaker: RADIO NEWSCASTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And, as we told you earlier this afternoon, the governor met with the murder victim's father and mother, who urged him not to grant Beachum a pardon. Governor's aide Harry Mancuso spoke to us after that meeting.

dialogues.speaker: MANCUSO, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: This administration is determined to remain as tough on crime as it has always been, and we are determined to see justice done for the family of Amy Wilson and the people of this state.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see a large warehouse-like structure -- the loft building where Michelle Ziegler lived.  103 104 105 106 102. McCARDLE 103 Moving on to test the black phone.

dialogues.speaker: RINGING PHONE 104
dialogues.text: It's in the kitchen of Everett's condo. Barbara, his wife, goes to answer it.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: Hello... Yes, this is... yes, Steve's wife. Why? Has something happened to him?

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT'S FACE 105
dialogues.text: Wreathed in eerie light. Suddenly the light goes out.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: (in a hoarse whisper) Shit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We PULL BACK to see that Everett is trying to pick the lock of the outside door with a credit card. He has just dropped his flashlight; he picks it up again, and it shines for a moment on Michelle Ziegler's name on the buzzer. Everett monkeys with the credit card until he hears a CLICK. Only it isn't really a click. It's the SNAP of his CREDIT CARD breaking in half. He withdraws it and watches the other piece fall to the ground. His flashlight jiggles on it for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Shit! He looks guiltily over his shoulder. The streets are deserted. Stealthily, he reaches down and picks up an object out of the darkness. A tire iron. He rises. The wooden door has a windowed top. Everett taps against it gently, stealthily. The whole PANE SHATTERS with a resounding CRASH. Everett looks around again, reaches in, and turns the inside knob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He enters and hurries through the entryway. GLASS CRUNCHES under his feet.  107 108 109 103.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everett goes up the steps two at a time, panting. We can hear his BREATH sawing in and out of him. Three flights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everett reaches the top and runs down the hall. When he gets to Michelle's door he collapses against the wall, gasping. Finally, he wills himself away from the wall, staring at the column of stalwart locks on Michelle's door. Somewhat daunted, he nevertheless fits the wedge of the tire iron into the jamb. The door swings slowly open. Surprised, Everett stumbles in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everett's flashlight sweeps the loft space, revealing boxes, tapes, and stacks of paper everywhere. Everett kneels down to examine the contents of one box. Suddenly, a hand lashes forward and grips his arm.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Vultures!

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Jesus!

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Already the vultures come! Everett pulls away, staggers, hits a desk, and fumbles for the lamp switch. He turns it on. In the light, he sees an ELDERLY MAN sitting on the edge of Michelle's huge circular bed. He is slumped and droopy, but he is watching Everett like a hawk.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: So steal. Go ahead.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Mr. Ziegler? The Man makes no reply, but he sighs and slumps even further.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: I'm not a thief, Mr. Ziegler. I'ma friend of Michelle's. A colleague. Worked with her at the paper. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MR. ZIEGLER
dialogues.text: My friends, most of them knock.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Right. Sorry. (beat) I'm sorry about Michelle. I liked her a lot. She was a terrific reporter. Top- notch.

dialogues.speaker: MR. ZIEGLER
dialogues.text: So you come to give the eulogy?

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: No, I -- she was working on a story. See, there's a man, an innocent man, and they're going to execute him tonight. And I think there may be something in these papers that could save his life.

dialogues.speaker: MR. ZIEGLER
dialogues.text: Something Michelle did?

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Yeah. She was onto something. That's why I --

dialogues.speaker: MR. ZIEGLER
dialogues.text: So look. Everett glances at his watch: 6:45. He starts rummaging through boxes. As he does, Mr. Ziegler talks to him ina far-away voice. During the next few exchanges, we INTERCUT Everett's searching with Mr. Ziegler's talking and CLOSEUPS OF what Everett finds among Michelle's boxes: photos of atrocities, notes about other murder trials, pictures of chalk outlines, a bag of marijuana, etc. Dust rises in the air, and Everett coughs as he works.

dialogues.speaker: MR. ZIEGLER
dialogues.text: I've been going through her things, too. You see this? He holds up a little plastic horse. Everett looks up politely, but he's getting increasingly desperate.

dialogues.speaker: MR. ZIEGLER
dialogues.text: Gave it to her when she was nine. She loved it. Know what she named it? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: (checking his watch) No. What?

dialogues.speaker: MR. ZIEGLER
dialogues.text: Mr. Id. Can you imagine that? Nine years old. Mr. Id. Oh, she saved everything. Look at this. I don't know when she did it -- must have been four or five. He holds up a child's drawing. Not exactly "Green Pastures," but remarkably similar. Everett takes a cursory glance, and then looks again.

dialogues.speaker: PICTURE
dialogues.text: A daddy separated from a mommy and small daughter by a vast field. It's signed, "Gail."

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Do you know where you found this?

dialogues.speaker: MATERIAL
dialogues.text: dumped on the dining table. Everett's hand feverishly combing through the pile of documents, photos, clippings, tapes, and notes, all pertaining to the Beachum case. PULL BACK to show Mr. Ziegler is standing now, watching Everett work. Everett doesn't notice a notebook that he has dropped. Achingly, rheumatically, Mr. Ziegler bends down and picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: MR. ZIEGLER
dialogues.text: This anything?

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: (not even looking up) What?

dialogues.speaker: MR. ZIEGLER
dialogues.text: Says, ‘Warren Russel. Seventeen years. 4331 Knight Street. Interviewed July seventh at own request.' Everett grabs the notebook and reads.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: ‘Bought soda and left. Saw nothing. Something fishy here?' (looking up) Thank you, Mr. Ziegler. Michelle -- she would have been one of the best.  110 106.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luther Plunkitt walks quietly to Frank's cell. Reedy sits behind him and types in the chronological: "19:04 -- Warden Plunkitt enters Deathwatch cell." Plunkitt lifts one hand in a gesture of apology.

dialogues.speaker: PLUNKITT
dialogues.text: Sorry, Frank. We're gonna have to ask Mrs. Beachum to leave now.

dialogues.speaker: BEACHUM
dialogues.text: Give us a minute, okay?

dialogues.speaker: PLUNKITT
dialogues.text: Sure. Plunkitt retreats, and Frank and Bonnie face each other.

dialogues.speaker: BONNIE
dialogues.text: Oh God.

dialogues.speaker: BEACHUM
dialogues.text: No. No, baby.

dialogues.speaker: BONNIE
dialogues.text: I swear I don't know how I'm gonna...

dialogues.speaker: BEACHUM
dialogues.text: I won't get a chance later, you know, to say good-bye. You take care of our little girl, Bonnie.

dialogues.speaker: BONNIE
dialogues.text: You know I will, baby. Beachum hands her the letter he wrote for Gail.

dialogues.speaker: BEACHUM
dialogues.text: And you give her this. Don't forget. It's not much, but it's the only thing!-- He stops, struggles for composure.

dialogues.speaker: BONNIE
dialogues.text: It'll be precious to her, Frank. It'll be her most precious thing. Her tears are falling now. Beachum's voice is trembling.

dialogues.speaker: BEACHUM
dialogues.text: I sure didn't mean for this to happen to us, Bonnie. I meant to be there for you. (MORE ) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: BEACHUM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I wanted -- I wanted to see my little daughter grow up. Now you're gonna have to do that for the both of us, Bonnie.

dialogues.speaker: BONNIE
dialogues.text: We gotta be thankful for the time we had, Frank. It's just -- it was too short. It was so short, Frank.

dialogues.speaker: BEACHUM
dialogues.text: Least we made Gail together. We made something beautiful in this world. When you look at her, you gotta remember me, all right? Can you do that?

dialogues.speaker: BONNIE
dialogues.text: Oh, Frank, I'm so scared.

dialogues.speaker: BEACHUM
dialogues.text: If I can see you, you know? At the end there, if I can see your face...

dialogues.speaker: BONNIE
dialogues.text: I'm gonna be there, Frank. And I'll talk to you. Every day I'll talk to you.

dialogues.speaker: BEACHUM
dialogues.text: You talk to me, baby. I'm gonna need to hear you talking to me. Crying, she studies his face, trying to memorize it. Beachum bites his lip, but it quivers anyway. Finally, Bonnie collapses in his arms, and they both break down, sobbing.

dialogues.speaker: BONNIE
dialogues.text: Oh God, Frank. How did this ever happen to us?

dialogues.speaker: BEACHUM
dialogues.text: God bless you, Bonnie. You gave me the only life I had that was worth a damn. God bless you, baby. God bless you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An upstairs window. An elderly black woman, ANGELA RUSSEL, pokes her head out and looks down.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. RUSSEL
dialogues.text: Who's there? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Everett is standing on the stoop, ringing her bell. Behind him, some very young, very tough-looking kids are circling his car.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Steve Everett, ma'am. I'm a reporter with the News.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The window slams shut. Everett waits for a moment, wondering, eyeing the nasty-looking kids. The door opens. Mrs. Russel is a powerful-looking woman in her fifties. She wears a shapeless floral housedress that ends at the shoulders and the knees, and she twists a gold locket that she wears around her neck. Suddenly she yells.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. RUSSEL
dialogues.text: Go home! Everett is startled. It takes him a moment to realize that she is yelling at the kids behind him.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. RUSSEL
dialogues.text: Quit casing that man's car. It's your dinner time. Go home. The kids edge away sulkily. Mrs. Russel examines Everett.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. RUSSEL
dialogues.text: Sorry about them kids.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: No, that's all right. I'm just so, I mean I'm amazed I could find you here after six years --

dialogues.speaker: MRS. RUSSEL
dialogues.text: You thought I mighta moved to the suburbs? (beat) Come on in. She turns and Everett follows her in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is stifling and airless. Mrs. Russel opens a window. The steady DIN of TRAFFIC fills the room. The room is sparsely furnished -- a rocking chair, a TV, a ratty couch, a dresser with pictures on it. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: So you're...

dialogues.speaker: MRS. RUSSEL
dialogues.text: Angela Russel.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: And Warren...

dialogues.speaker: MRS. RUSSEL
dialogues.text: My grandson. Everett has caught sight of a picture on Mrs. Russell's dresser. We see it, too -- a younger Mrs. Russel with a smiling teenager wearing a backward baseball cap.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: That Warren?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. RUSSEL
dialogues.text: It is. You wanna tell me why you're here?

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Mrs. Russel, it's very important that I talk to Warren. I need to see him tonight.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. RUSSEL
dialogues.text: Is that right? And what could be so important, if you don't mind my askin'?

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: There's a man on death row, and he's going to be executed tonight. They say he killed this grocery store cashier Amy Wilson six years ago. I think he's innocent. And I also think your grandson may have... may know something about it.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. RUSSEL
dialogues.text: Now why would you think a thing like that?

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Because he was the only other one there.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. RUSSEL
dialogues.text: Oh? And how do we know that?

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Because... the witnesses didn't see anybody else. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MRS. RUSSEL
dialogues.text: So there was witnesses even though nobody else was there? Now help me out here. I'm getting confused.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: All right, yes. There were two witnesses. An accountant and a housewife.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. RUSSEL
dialogues.text: White people.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Yes...

dialogues.speaker: MRS. RUSSEL
dialogues.text: And I'll just bet that Amy Wilson was white too, wasn't she?

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: She was, but I don't think --

dialogues.speaker: MRS. RUSSEL
dialogues.text: You don't think these nice white people would ever kill that nice white girl. But they all looked around and, whaddaya know, there was a black boy.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: No, it wasn't like that. It was!-- Mrs. Russel, think back. Six years ago. Was Warren using drugs?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. RUSSEL
dialogues.text: (as if to an idiot) Yeah. He was using drugs.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Does he own a gun -- or did he then?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. RUSSEL
dialogues.text: Oh, they all got guns, Mr. Everett. Don't you know that? All those black drug-fiend boys got guns.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Can I just talk to him, Mrs. Russel? Do you know where he is?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. RUSSEL
dialogues.text: Yes, I do. And no, you can't.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: An innocent man is going to be killed! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MRS. RUSSEL
dialogues.text: Well, I seen a lot of innocent folks get killed in this part of town. But it's funny: I ain't never seen you here before.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Mrs. Russel, I know you think this is a race thing. It's not a race thing. That innocent man on death row -- he's black, too. Did you know that? They're going to kill him at midnight. I'm just -- I just need to know the facts.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. RUSSEL
dialogues.text: Only fact I know, Mr. Everett, is that my grandson Warren been in his grave now going on three years. Stabbed out there in the park. She wraps her hands around the locket and is suddenly near tears.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. RUSSEL
dialogues.text: My Warren was a loving child. And I didn't see you coming around looking for the facts when he was killed. No one came around looking for the facts then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everett is driving, fumbling with his RADIO, getting STATIC. He bangs on it angrily -- we can see he's frustrated and upset, and not principally about the radio.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: (banging) Loser!... Fuck! He finally finds a station that comes in clearly.

dialogues.speaker: RADIO NEWSCASTER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: +. and we're told he is now having the last meal he requested earlier -- steak and French fries and Budweiser beer. Oddly enough, he also requested two six- packs of Coke...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THROUGH the windshield, we see that he is coming up on Dead Man's Curve, the very curve that took Michelle Ziegler's life. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: RADIO NEWSCASTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: «+. Prison authorities agreed to one six-pack, but refused his request for a second. And, in case you're just tuning in, we'll repeat our top story. Convicted killer Frank Beachum has for the first time confessed to his crime... Everett's face: thunderstruck.

dialogues.speaker: RADIO NEWSCASTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ...- However, a source close to the governor's office says that despite Beachum's expression of remorse for the murders of Amy Wilson and her unborn child six years ago, the execution will proceed as scheduled at one minute after midnight tonight.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: Everett pulls up next to the shattered remains of Michelle's car. He gets out, slams the door, and strides over to the nearby vending machine. He drops in some quarters, and pushes the Dr. Pepper button. The can drops down with a loud THUNK. Everett takes it out and heads back toward his car, but when he reaches the ruins of Michelle's car, he stops, drops the Dr. Pepper, and squats down. He rocks for a moment in despair, seemingly communing with the hole in the shattered windshield. The CAMERA GOES THROUGH the hole, INTO the dark. There, strangely, we see Everett's little daughter, Kate. He is looking out at us curiously. He reaches up and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: .-. Kate grabs Everett's hand. Everett is now sitting by her bedside, gazing at his daughter. Kate strokes the hair on her father's forearm thoughtfully.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: (happy to see him) Why are you here?

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: (forcing a laugh) Where else would I be, silly?

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Where did you go?

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Wild goose chase, m'dear. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: You... you went chasing?

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Chasing salvation, sweetie. Couldn't catch it.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: It disappeared. Poof! He makes a magician's gesture with his hands. Kate looks at him uncomprehendingly.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Hey. Sorry about today at the zoo. But I'll make it up to you, okay? You wanna go this weekend? We'll do Slow Zoo.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: And can we see the hippopotamus?

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Oh yeah. I already called him. He's expecting us.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: (fondly) My little daddy... I will go to sleep now.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Good move. He stands and moves to the door. For a moment, he watches his daughter lying there. Kate turns her head and peeks at Everett. Seeing him still there makes the girl smile.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Go to sleep, darlin'. He turns out the lights and goes into the hall outside. For a moment, he pauses and leans against the wall with his head bowed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara is sitting over an empty cup of coffee, rubbing the fingers of her left hand with her right. Everett sits down next to her, almost says something, and finds he cannot. Then he looks at what she's doing with her hands. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Barbara has worked off her wedding ring. Now she sets it on the tabletop, as far from her -- and as close to Everett -- as she can.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: If that were a bullet, you'd be dead. Everett picks up the ring and examines it. The inscription on the inner curve reads: "Steve and Barbara." A long silence.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: So I guess -- what? Bob called you?

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: What's the difference who called me? Everett shrugs. Right; makes no difference.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: It's over, Ev. I know you're going to apologize. I know you'll try and do better. Honey, it's too late.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: (reeling) Won't this be kind of... hard on the kid?

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: Good time to think of it, Ev.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Look, I can change. Can't we just erase all this? I've had a ridiculous, terrible day -- everything I did was wrong. Everything I thought was --

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: Ev, it isn't just today.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: (desperate) Yeah, but today was the end of it. Today I understood -- Look, I know I'm easily tempted. I know that. But is that so -- Barbara, I love you. I'm falling apart here, and it's my own goddamn fault. I need you. I want to put the pieces back together. Barbara looks at him very gently and ruefully. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: Ev, I feel sorry for you. You and your famous nose for a story. You think you can just sniff your way along, you know, from one hunch to another, one woman to another, one drink to another when you're drinking. But people aren't stories, Ev. You can't line up all the facts and think you know something. Your hunches are shit, Ev. Even when they're right, they're shit.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: They're all I've got.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: Well, I hope they do somebody some good one of these days, because they haven't done a thing for this marriage. (beat) I've packed your stuff. You can take it now or come back for it later.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Barbara --

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: Get out of here, Ev. (beat) Get out! He sits for a moment, staring down at the table, pressing his lips together so they won't tremble. Then he puts the ring in his shirt pocket, gets up, and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luther Plunkitt bursts through a door, his rage suggested by the ferocity of his pace. Behind him, Reverend Shillerman, trotting to keep up.

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND SHILLERMAN
dialogues.text: +. of course, you know, from time to time, the governor's aides will, uh, phone me on matters of concern to the governor himself... Plunkitt attempts to blast through another door, but it's locked. He smacks it and does a U-turn. Shillerman follows. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND SHILLERMAN
dialogues.text: ++. now in the course of spiritual counseling and ministrations, it's true that I might have misunderstood something the prisoner might have said to me... Plunkitt passes a small holding area. A GUARD leans out.

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: Warden, South Wing is looking for you. Plunkitt pushes through an exterior door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Plunkitt strides toward the center of the yard.

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND SHILLERMAN
dialogues.text: .-. but if he says to me, meaning the prisoner, says to me ‘I'm sorry' and it's under these extreme conditions, then when the governor's aide calls me, expecting -- Plunkitt whirls to face Shillerman.

dialogues.speaker: PLUNKITT
dialogues.text: Shillerman, you know what you've done, don't you? Now I have to call the governor's office. I have to issue a retraction to the press, tell them there was no confession. Beachum has his own pastor coming in anyway. So what did you think you were doing?

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND SHILLERMAN
dialogues.text: Well, sir, I guess I --

dialogues.speaker: PLUNKITT
dialogues.text: You made me look unprofessional, Shillerman. Not a good thing to do. Spiritually speaking. Plunkitt leaves Shillerman in the middle of the empty yard.

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND SHILLERMAN
dialogues.text: (calling after him) If any of the men feel they could use some counseling tonight, I'll be here. Long as they need me. I'll be here.  119 117.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the same bar we see Everett in at the beginning of the movie, during his last conversation with Michelle. Tonight, Everett is back on the bottle. The bartender, Neil, pours him another. ON the TV, a BALL GAME.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: You sure you want to do this, Ev?

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Does a bear shit... on Goldilocks?

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: I don't know. No one ever asked me that before.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Trouble with having a kid. Fucks up your quips.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: So you're seriously rolling off the wagon. Must have been a rough day.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Lost my wife, my kid, and my fuckin' job. Izzat pretty rough?

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: You lose your car, too? ‘Cause if you're planning on driving --

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: (already pretty sauced) Hey, Neil. I am the greatest driver on the continent.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: I see. I'm talking to a dead guy. Would you leave me your stamp collection? Everett downs some more and fingers the empty pretzel bowl.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Madder music and more munchies, Neil. Haven't eaten hardly all day. Neil replaces the pretzels. On the TV, a NEWS REPORT is coming on about Beachum. Everett lights a cigarette, but he can barely get the flame to the tip. Neil looks at him. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 119 TRUE CRIME - Rev. 5/11/98 118.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ, Everett. Go the fuck home, will ya?

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Got no home, Neil-o. No fucking home. He reaches into his shirt pocket and pulls out the ring. Neil walks away to watch the TV report. Everett stares moonily at the ring, examines the inside, and then fumbles it. As it spins on the counter, we SLIGHTLY OVERCRANK. On the TV is the now-familiar picture of Amy Wilson in her drab blouse, wearing the locket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ring on the bar and the locket on TV seem to line up for a moment, gleaming together.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHBACK
dialogues.text: Twisting the small locket around her neck.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO PRESENT
dialogues.text: Trying hard to focus through his alcohol-induced haze.

dialogues.speaker: FREDERICK ROBERTSON
dialogues.text: Amy's father, on TELEVISION.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERTSON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: .+. For ninety-six dollars, and he took her ring and a locket I gave her for her sixteenth birthday...

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: So you're...

dialogues.speaker: MRS. RUSSEL
dialogues.text: Angela Russel.

dialogues.speaker: LOCKET
dialogues.text: The florid, engraved initials: "A.R."

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO PRESENT
dialogues.text: His eyes on the ring, on the picture on TV, on the picture in his mind. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Suddenly Everett stands up. He can barely stay on his feet. The look in his eyes is wild, desperate. CLOSE ON Everett. FADE OUT.

dialogues.speaker: IN _EVERETT'S MIND
dialogues.text: Beachum is already on his way to the bathroom, but this time we watch him from the front of the store.

dialogues.speaker: BEACHUM
dialogues.text: You're not always gonna do me this way, are you?

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: I swear, Frank. We just had some extra expenses, end of the school year and all.

dialogues.speaker: BEACHUM
dialogues.text: It's cool. July Fifteenth. Hey, I'm just gonna use the bathroom, okay?

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: You know where, right? As Beachum goes into the entryway toward the bathroom, we hear a NOISE at the FRONT DOOR. We WHIP-PAN TO the door, and in comes WARREN RUSSEL, looking nervous and mean. He scans the room and saunters over to the counter.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Help you? Warren whips out a small gun and points it at Amy.

dialogues.speaker: WARREN
dialogues.text: Gimme the money. Terrified, Amy opens the cash register and begins pulling out bills.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Don't hurt me, okay? Okay? Just take it. He motions with the gun, and she hands him all the cash from the drawer. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WARREN
dialogues.text: That it? That all you got?

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. It's Fourth of July. We haven't been that busy. Warren stares at her, hopped up, not ready to go yet. Amy is weeping with fright.

dialogues.speaker: AMY'S LOCKET
dialogues.text: It glints in the sun. We can see the initials: "A.R." Warren points the gun at the locket around Amy's throat.

dialogues.speaker: WARREN
dialogues.text: Gimme that. Quick! Amy moves her hand protectively toward the locket, which is hanging on her chest, just below her throat.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: (crying out) Please! Not that! In the rear of the store, the TOILET FLUSHES. Warren looks back toward the bathroom, startled. His face: wide-eyed. Suddenly he SHOOTS Amy in the chest. Amy falls back behin the counter, gurgling. In a flash, Warren is on top of her. He rips the locket from around her neck and pulls a ring off her finger. We can hear the bathroom DOOR OPENING. He sees the service entrance, jumps up and runs out. We see him scampering through the service entryway, out the screen door, through the parking lot to his beat-up car. The MOTOR is already RUNNING. Warren jumps in, tosses the locket on the seat beside him, and PEELS OUT. We see Warren's car leave the parking lot and drive. About a block away, a man is mowing his lawn and looks up at the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Warren drives. An oncoming car. It is Porterhouse. Steam is coming from his hood, and Porterhouse is looking desperately at his dashboard indicators. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He doesn't notice Warren. He spots Pocum's and puts on his turn signal.

dialogues.speaker: LOCKET
dialogues.text: next to Warren. We PULL BACK, and now we are looking at the locket on TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everett, thunderstruck, drunk out of his mind. He wobbles determinedly toward the door. Neil is still watching the TV.

dialogues.speaker: TV ANCHOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (to his co-anchor) And, still on the Beachum execution story, you'll recall that report we got about an hour ago in which... Everett has reached the door. He grabs the handle and pulls it open. The edge smacks into his forehead -- hard. It draws blood.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Ow! Shit! Blood seeps down his brow and onto his fingers. Neil notices him leaving and yells after him, but Everett is already gone.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: I hope you're not driving, Ev! Hey, Ev! Neil turns his attention back to the TV, and we PAN UP TO it.

dialogues.speaker: TV ANCHOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ... Frank Beachum was said to have confessed his crime. Well, apparently that report was in error. We're now told that Beachum has not confessed and is still scheduled to go to his execution just about an hour from now without having expressed a word of remorse for the killing six years ago of twenty-year-old co-ed Amy Wilson...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four guards head toward Beachum's cell. Each carries a plastic riot shield; rubber truncheons dangle from their belts. The lead guard carries a brown paper bag.  124 125 122.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door snaps open. Beachum bolts upright, his eyes darting between the clock and Luther Plunkitt. Beachum is sitting with his own pastor, REVEREND FLOWERS, who now rises. The lead guard hands the paper bag to Plunkitt.

dialogues.speaker: PLUNKITT
dialogues.text: Reverend Flowers, I'm just going to ask you to step into another room for a moment, all right? Flowers nods, nods to Beachum, and steps away. We can hear Reedy in the b.g., typing the chronological.

dialogues.speaker: PLUNKITT
dialogues.text: Now, Frank, this is the change of clothes we talked about. I'm gonna ask you now to put these clothes on, including the special underpants that are provided for hygienic reasons. This is required, and I have to ask you if you're going to give me any problems with this. Beachum passively accepts the bag.

dialogues.speaker: PLUNKITT
dialogues.text: Good. Now, it would be wise at this point, Frank, if you took the opportunity to use the toilet, for your own comfort. Since there might not be an opportunity later on. I'1l wait outside. Plunkitt exits. Beachum stares at the paper bag in his hands.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: We're working very hard to stay in our lane. With minimal success.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: C'mon, ya motherfucking hunk of tin! Ya shuddering pile of roasted shit, come on!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car veering, nearly plowing through a crowd, back on course, veering again. Over a bridge -- skimming the guard rail in a shower of sparks. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: KEE-RUNCH! We BASH into the rear of a CAR sitting at a red light. The car slams into the car in front of it. Sounds of SHATTERED HEADLIGHTS and TAILLIGHTS dripping to the pavement. Angry drivers emerge from their cars. Everett backs up. Everett starts to drive away, making a huge arc around them. Everett moves into the intersection against the red light. A car entering from across street smashes on its brakes. Everett clips the car's rear fender, leaving a nice crater.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helpless and childlike, Beachum stands in his blue plastic diapers. Quickly, he covers them with loose green trousers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reporters are gathered alongside a number of protestors holding a candlelight vigil and a handful of death- penalty supporters. A WILMA FRANCIS confers with her FIELD PRODUCER. Their crew eavesdrops.

dialogues.speaker: WILMA FRANCIS
dialogues.text: So there are two executioners? What, they each have a button?

dialogues.speaker: FIELD PRODUCER
dialogues.text: They each have a button, but a computer scrambles the circuits so nobody knows which button actually does the trick.

dialogues.speaker: WILMA FRANCIS
dialogues.text: Can we talk to one of them?

dialogues.speaker: FIELD PRODUCER
dialogues.text: They're kept anonymous. For security reasons.

dialogues.speaker: WILMA FRANCIS
dialogues.text: Man, can you imagine? Who are these guys?

dialogues.speaker: LETHAL INJECTION MACHINE 128
dialogues.text: The tubes leading through the wall, a red button that will activate the plungers, a black button that shuts everything down, and another red button to activate the plungers. We PULL BACK to reveal a heavy man standing next to the second red button. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He is the second executioner. He scans the room. There is Reuben Skycock, hovering near the machine. Beyond him, stands McCardle, next to the shelf of colored phones. There are Dr. Waters and his nurse. The second executioner looks down at his watch, then up again. Now he spies the man he's looking for: the executioner, the man we have been following throughout the film. The executioner comes to the machine, shakes Skycock's hand, nods to the second executioner, and assumes his position next to the first red button.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dark and scary, with the same mean-looking kids hanging out. Suddenly, Everett's battered CAR comes SCREAMING around the corner. The kids take one look and scatter. The car mounts the sidewalk, smashes into a garbage can, slips back down into the street and comes to a STEAMING, shuddering halt. We hear a DISTANT BELCH.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wall clock reads: 11:30. PANNING DOWN, we FIND Bonnie Beachum sitting alone among the plastic tables and chairs. The loud BANGING of a METAL DOOR opening startles her. A PRISON CUSTODIAN sticks his head in.

dialogues.speaker: CUSTODIAN
dialogues.text: Oh. Sorry. The door bangs shut. Bonnie folds her hand in her skirt. Her sunken eyes stare at nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everett leans on the BUZZER. He looks up. The windows are dark. Everett looks at his watch: 11:32. He jams the BUZZER AGAIN AND AGAIN, the frustration building in him. Then he hits the door, hammering the frame with his already-bloody fist. He kicks it. Finally he collapses against the door, the wood against the blood on his forehead. He groans, extends his arms along the wood, and then slumps, the energy oozing out of him. One last slap. The CAMERA PULLS BACK. And then... Angela Russel opens the door. She is wearing a bathrobe. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MRS. RUSSEL
dialogues.text: I was hoping you'd come back. I swear it to Jesus. Everett straightens, tries to pull himself together.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Mrs. Russel, you and I need to --

dialogues.speaker: MRS. RUSSEL
dialogues.text: We gotta hurry, Mr. Everett. A little stunned, and very drunk, Everett grabs Mrs. Russel's arm, and they head toward his car.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. RUSSEL
dialogues.text: That Robertson man -- on the T.V., you know, the girl's father. I saw him. And then I started in remembering that night when Warren gave me that locket --

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Because it had the same initials!--

dialogues.speaker: MRS. RUSSEL
dialogues.text: Her maiden name, and I was remembering Warren's face that night -- oh, I could always read that boy's face. Suddenly Mrs. Russel is near tears.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. RUSSEL
dialogues.text: Oh God, Warren. Warren. He did a real bad thing, Mr. Everett. He wasn't a bad boy, but I know he did a real bad thing. They get in the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everett puts the key in the ignition, and turns it over.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. RUSSEL
dialogues.text: They gonna kill that man in less than half an hour. We can't get to the prison in that time.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: You're right, lady. Fasten your seatbelt!  133 134 135 TRUE CRIME - Rev. 5/11/98 126.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FLUORESCENT LIGHTS, BUZZING, strobing. The guards lead Beachum down the corridor to the death chamber. Reverend Flowers strides behind the procession.

dialogues.speaker: FLOWERS
dialogues.text: .+. I will say of the Lord, He is my refuge and my fortress; my God; in Him will I trust. Surely He shall deliver thee from the snare of the fowler...

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT 134
dialogues.text: The car is zooming along. Everett's driving is erratic, to say the least. But his mind is on something else.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: (half to himself) The locket is good. The locket is good, but...

dialogues.speaker: MRS. RUSSEL
dialogues.text: There's this boy sold Warren a gun around that time.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. RUSSEL
dialogues.text: He's in jail -- this boy. Might talk to them if they give him some time off. Everett turns toward her, and the car veers.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: I could kiss you.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. RUSSEL
dialogues.text: Watch the damn road!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beachum is watching the strap-down team, a ghostly, empty look on his face. When the gurney is ready, the strap- down team very quickly lifts him onto it. He looks up at the clock. The men pull the leather straps across his body and fasten them.  136 137 138 127.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT 136
dialogues.text: Everett's car rips recklessly through an intersection, fishtails wildly, almost loses it, recovers, and accelerates hard, the ENGINE cranked to its limit. The car spews blue smoke.

dialogues.speaker: ABANDON
dialogues.text: Everett passes a row of cars in the oncoming lane. Mrs. Russel pushes against the dashboard with both hands.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. RUSSEL
dialogues.text: You drunk, now aren't I right?

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Yes, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. RUSSEL
dialogues.text: You a terrible driver, you know that? A city bus looms ahead. Everett's car careens wildly to avoid it.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Yes, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. RUSSEL
dialogues.text: Let me drive. What kind of white man drives a shitbox like this anyway? Suddenly the car is filled with red and white light -- and the sound of SIRENS.

dialogues.speaker: REAR-VIEW MIRROR
dialogues.text: A police cruiser is following them, and we see a second one come skidding out of a McDonald's lot.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. RUSSEL
dialogues.text: Gun it, mister! Everett flashes her a scary grin.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: We go fast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A nurse snaps Beachum's sheet down to his waist. She attaches two pads to his chest and runs the wires over the gurney's side.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: This is just for the E.K.G. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She goes behind a white screen and returns holding a cotton ball and a needle. She pushes the needle through its wrapper and swabs the bend of Beachum's elbow.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: This'1l be easier if you make a fist.

dialogues.speaker: PLUNKITT
dialogues.text: watching, hoping she'll find the vein easily. She does. The connecting tube runs over the wall. She sticks two Band-Aids over the needle in an X to hold it fast. She tugs the sheet back up to Beachum's throat. Plunkitt watches Beachum's face. It's the face of any frightened patient on a gurney, looking to a nurse for reassurance. To his chagrin, Plunkitt finds his right hand trembling against his pants leg. He slips the hand into his pocket and moves to a more private corner of the room. He takes a deep breath.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT'S REAR-VIEW MIRROR 139
dialogues.text: One of the cruisers zigs to the side and overtakes Everett.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: Everett looks out the window and sees the side of the cruiser edging closer his car. He hears the cop's LOUDSPEAKER.

dialogues.speaker: COP, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Pull over! Pull over and stop the car! Everett takes his foot off the gas and the car slows at once.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. RUSSEL
dialogues.text: Well, don't slow down now! The cruiser moves in front of Everett's car and we see its brake lights flare. That's when Everett hauls the steering wheel to the left and stomps on the gas. Everett's car shoots forward into the empty pocket left by the cruiser. Everett speeds into the night as the cruisers get going again behind him.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. RUSSEL
dialogues.text: You had a real car, we would have lost ‘em.  140 141 142 143 144 129.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quiet now, a blurred MURMURING of VOICES. His body stilled by straps, Beachum's eyes dart around the room. They find Plunkitt talking softly to a guard; the sweeping hands of the clock; the saline solution running into Beachum's arm; and finally the window behind which the witnesses will sit.
