Beachum hears the sounds of PLASTIC BENCHES SCRAPING behind the blinds as they enter the room. Is Bonnie there? He peers into the dark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It looms in the dark just as we remember it: the same yellow lights. We hear APPROACHING SIRENS because --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everett's car is coming at a blinding speed, followed by the two WAILING POLICE CRUISERS.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: (yelling over

dialogues.speaker: ENGINE ROAR
dialogues.text: Mrs. Russel, I have to tell you something.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. RUSSEL
dialogues.text: what? (yelling back) at? One of the cruisers begins to pull alongside them.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: (yelling) I want you to prepare yourself, all right? I'm about to attempt a maneuver... THROUGH the WINDSHIELD -- Dead Man's Curve, approaching very, very fast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everett's car burns over the straight edge of the boulevard and tears into the curve. Mrs. Russel shrieks. Everett shrieks, too. Everett's foot comes off the gas and hovers over the brake. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The two cruisers shoot past the car into the curve. Everett's CAR begins to SKID. Everett turns into the skid. The CAR SCREECHES under him. The world goes by in a carousel blur. The two cruisers lift into the air as they break across the curb. One slides into the car lot. The other follows and SMASHES broadside into the first one's TRUNK. Both cars sit, smoldering, while the police inside them slowly climb out. Everett straightens the car out and hits the gas.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: They really ought to do something about that place. He looks over at Mrs. Russel. She stares straight ahead, her jaw dropped, her body as rigid as a tree trunk.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. RUSSEL
dialogues.text: Now that's some driving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A GRANDFATHER CLOCK TICKS QUIETLY. On the STEREO, DEBUSSY'S "Clair de Lune." A Persian rug, rare books, a dainty escritoire by the window. MRS. LOWENSTEIN is bent over her needlework. Mr. Lowenstein, the paper's owner and the governor's pal, sits in a leather wing chair, writing a letter. SIRENS. DISTANT at first, but insistent.

dialogues.speaker: LOWENSTEIN
dialogues.text: Must be something going on.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LOWENSTEIN
dialogues.text: A fire, maybe. Or another accident up on the curve. Another sound. A RUMBLING, CLATTERING sound. Mr. Lowenstein glances at the grandfather clock: 11:48. He stands, pulling his bathrobe closed over his silk pajamas. He moves to the window and peers out toward the street below.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT'S CAR
dialogues.text: Its muffler unhinged and dragging, pulls to a stop ina shower of sparks. The hellish METALLIC BANGING SUBSIDES into a HISS. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Everett rushes from the car and helps support what appears to be a very shaky black woman. They hurry to the front door.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LOWENSTEIN
dialogues.text: What is it, dear?

dialogues.speaker: LOWENSTEIN
dialogues.text: It's... Steve Everett. From the paper.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LOWENSTEIN
dialogues.text: Oh? One of your reporters?

dialogues.speaker: LOWENSTEIN
dialogues.text: Mm. A dyed-in-the-wool sonuvabitch. But he's a goddamned bulldog with a story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tan PHONE RINGS. McCardle picks it up. McCARDLE McCardle... Yes, sir. He replaces the phone and presses the intercom button. Zachary Platt, the deputy warden, picks up McCardle's call. McCARDLE (0.S.) We have a go. Platt nods to Plunkitt. Plunkitt looks at the clock. Midnight. He removes the folded death warrant from his pocket. Platt pulls a cord that raises the blinds covering the witness window.

dialogues.speaker: THROUGH WINDOW
dialogues.text: The stark white death chamber. The gurney. Beachum's face poking out from beneath the white sheet. Plunkitt reads from the death warrant. Bonnie jerks forward on her bench. Beachum cranes his neck, desperately searching the window for her face. Bonnie moves to the window.

dialogues.speaker: PLUNKITT
dialogues.text: (finishing) +. by the state of California and sentenced to death by lethal injection. Have you anything to say? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Beachum says nothing, but scans the window, which we now see to be one-way glass. He can see only the chamber's reflection. Unseen by Beachum, Bonnie presses her face against the window and mouths the silent words, "I love you." Plunkitt looks at the clock. The second hand is sweeping up to 12:01. McCardle looks toward Plunkitt. He waits for a signal. The executioner's hand lingers near the red button. He waits. Platt glances at a clock. Thirty seconds past 12:01. The guard near him lifts an eyebrow. McCardle looks at Plunkitt, then at the clock. It's sweeping past 12:02. MOVING CLOSER ON Plunkitt. He appears to be frozen. CLOSER INTO his face and then his eyes, still and distant. Slowly, he turns TOWARD CAMERA and nods deeply to the mirror. McCardle nods. The executioner nods. Both executioners look at each other, ready to coordinate their actions. They push the red buttons.

dialogues.speaker: BONNIE'S FACE
dialogues.text: Full of anguish and love.

dialogues.speaker: BEACHUM'S FACE
dialogues.text: Looking desperately for her, mouthing the words, "I love you" to the empty glass. WIDEN -- the first syringe, the sodium pentothal, plunging slowly down. The arm tube with the sodium pentothal streaming through it.

dialogues.speaker: BEACHUM'S FACE
dialogues.text: He grits his teeth, his eyes flutter, he strains to keep them open. Suddenly, the black TELEPHONE RINGS. McCardle jumps. He snaps up the handset. The executioners look at one another. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: McCARDLE (yelling out) Yes, sir... But it's too late! Platt is frozen. McCardle is speechless. The executioners stand stunned. Suddenly Plunkitt is moving, looking neither right or left, pushing through the death chamber like a broken- field runner. In a single motion, he rips away the Band- Aid from Beachum's arm and brings the IV tube with it. He throws it to the ground. Blood spurts from Beachum's arm. Solution spurts from the writhing IV tube on the ground.

dialogues.speaker: BONNIE'S FACE
dialogues.text: Breathless, speechless, silently screaming. Behind her, the witnesses are on their feet.

dialogues.speaker: BEACHUM'S FACE
dialogues.text: Eyes closed, empty, gone.

dialogues.speaker: PLUNKITT
dialogues.text: Doctor! We gotta save this man's life! Dr. Waters is standing in the corner, within eyesight of the lethal injection console. He looks at it. The first syringe is completely empty, but the other two are still full. The second plunger begins to go down.

dialogues.speaker: DR. WATERS
dialogues.text: It's only the pentothal! Nurse! Dr. Waters, the nurse, McCardle, and two guards converge on Beachum's gurney. Platt reaches over and pushes the black button. The lethal-injection CONSOLE HISSES to a halt. A strange BANGING sound. It is --

dialogues.speaker: BONNIE
dialogues.text: Her eyes wide, her mouth open, her arms extended: She is pounding on the window with her fists, screaming.

dialogues.speaker: BONNIE
dialogues.text: Frank! Frank! The RHYTHMIC POUNDING SEGUES INTO another sound, a RHYTHMIC JINGLING as we...

dialogues.speaker: JINGLE BELLS 147
dialogues.text: PULL BACK -- A SANTA CLAUS is shaking them on the sidewalk outside the Union Station Mall. People toss money in his pot. His voice sounds vaguely familiar as the CAMERA SWEEPS PAST.

dialogues.speaker: SANTA CLAUS
dialogues.text: It's official. It's for charity. It's for kids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The place is decked out for Christmas. The CAMERA FINDS Steve Everett entering a toy store.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bright colors, happy MUSIC, fuzzy stuffed animals. And an unusually bright and attractive COUNTER GIRL.

dialogues.speaker: COUNTER GIRL
dialogues.text: Hey, Ev. Kate like that dalmatian?

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Loved it. Even my ex managed a convincing display of affection. So now I need something even better for Christmas.

dialogues.speaker: COUNTER GIRL
dialogues.text: Sheep dog? Collie? Saint Bernard?

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: You got a hippopotamus? The Girl grins, goes to a shelf, and picks out a strangely familiar-looking stuffed hippopotamus.

dialogues.speaker: COUNTER GIRL
dialogues.text: Check it out. Local designer. Based on the one at the zoo.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Beautiful. Can a homeless man afford it?

dialogues.speaker: COUNTER GIRL
dialogues.text: You're not homeless.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: I'm jobless, I'm wifeless, and I live in a hotel. Unless you want to put me up.

dialogues.speaker: COUNTER GIRL
dialogues.text: In the first place, everybody says you have a big, fat book contract... (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Money's already spent.

dialogues.speaker: COUNTER GIRL
dialogues.text: In the second place, everybody says you're about to win the Pulitzer Prize or something...

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Everybody's being real optimistic.

dialogues.speaker: COUNTER GIRL
dialogues.text: And in the third place, I have a boyfriend.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Aw, that's nice. He in town for the holidays?

dialogues.speaker: COUNTER GIRL
dialogues.text: (giggling) Cash or charge, Ev?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everett comes out of the mall, breathes in the cool air, and lights a cigarette. Behind him and a few yards away, the Santa Claus is plying his trade. The voice is familiar.

dialogues.speaker: SANTA CLAUS
dialogues.text: Gimme some charity. Gimme some charity here on toast. It's for kids. It's official. Gimme some charity on toast. Everett whirls. It's the Pussy Man in a Santa Claus costume, his red-streaked eyes peering from under the elf's cap.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Shit.

dialogues.speaker: PUSSY MAN
dialogues.text: Steve! You got charity! Now you're famous, you're rich and famous, you got charity money on toast. Shaking his head, Everett pulls a ten out of his pocket and gives it to him.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Take it, before my wife does. And get out of here. Go drink yourself to death. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PUSSY MAN
dialogues.text: A ten? You got more money than that, Steve. You got money on toast. Everett glares at him.

dialogues.speaker: PUSSY MAN
dialogues.text: Okay, okay, newspaper man. I been out here two hours; I'm freezing my ass off. I'm going home.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: You don't have a home.

dialogues.speaker: PUSSY MAN
dialogues.text: Hey, I got no wife, I got no elfs neither. You wanna be Santa Claus these days, you're on your own. He begins to shuffle away. Everett shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: I'm with you there, buddy. Santa Claus rides alone. Just then he hears a child's voice.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Da-deee! Come on! He turns. There, in the parking lot, is Frank Beachum being pulled along by his daughter, Gail. Bonnie is with him, laughing happily. Beachum suddenly stops when he sees Everett.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: Come on, Daddy! Come on now! Beachum stays another moment, giving Everett a long look. And Everett looks back intently, a bit the way he looked into the eyes of Porterhouse, and Beachum, too, that day in the prison. Then, slowly, Beachum raises his hand, lays his finger against his eyebrow, then lowers the finger and points it at Everett in a kind of salute. Everett raises his cigarette and tilts it back at him, and Beach laughs. Then Gail pulls him away, and Beachum wraps his arm around Bonnie's shoulder. The three of them go off. Everett smiles a deep, satisfied smile. He tosses his cigarette into the gutter and walks away. FADE OUT.
